title: Bursey v. SCDHEC
description: The Court affirmed a Court of Appeals decision, holding that an appeal was properly and timely taken from DHEC to the Mining Council, that upon appeal to the Circuit Court review under the Administrative Procedures Act was proper, and that the Court of Appeals correctly found substantial evidence supported the Council's decision.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Brett Bursey and Mining Association of South Carolina,
Respondents,
v.
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control,
Defendant,
and South Carolina Electric and Gas Company, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26166
Heard April 4, 2006 - Filed June 19, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Elizabeth B. Partlow, of Ogletree, Deakins, Nash, Smoak & Stewart, P.C., and Thomas Grant Eppink, of SCANA Corporation, both of Columbia, for petitioner.
Gregory Jacobs English, of Wyche, Burgess, Freeman & Parham, P.A., of Greenville, for respondent, Mining Association of South Carolina.
Brett Bursey, of Lexington, pro se respondent.
Etta R. Williams, of Columbia, for defendant.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Bursey
v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 600 S.E.2d 80 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm.
PROCEDURAL FACTS
As part of the dam remediation project on Lake Murray, petitioner (SCE&G) planned a back-up dam to be constructed by using materials that could be excavated on-site.Â  During this planning process, SCE&G contacted the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) to inquire into whether it would be necessary to obtain a mine operating permit.Â  DHEC responded by informing SCE&G that no permit would be needed, as the material SCE&G planned on excavating would be used on-site rather than being sold or transported to another location and, thus, did not fall within the definition of â€œmining.â€Â  In response to DHECâ€™s determination, nearby resident, Brett Bursey, and the Mining Association of South Carolina (Association) individually filed appeals with the Mining Council (Council).[1]Â  The Mining Council then agreed to conduct a hearing to review DHECâ€™s decision not to require a mine operating permit.Â  Following the hearing, the Mining Council found SCE&G was required to obtain a permit for the proposed actions.Â  The circuit court and Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  See Bursey, supra.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.   
         Should the decision of the Mining Council be vacated for lack of subject matter jurisdiction?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err by applying an inappropriate standard of review?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err by applying a substantial evidence standard of review to a legal determination by the Mining Council?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        IV. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err by finding respondentsâ€™ appeals to the Mining Council were timely?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
I. Subject matter jurisdiction
SCE&G argues the Council did not have subject matter jurisdiction to entertain respondentsâ€™ appeals because appeals to the Council can be taken only from the approval or denial of an application for an operating permit and cannot be taken from a decision not to require a permit.Â  SCE&G claims that such an appeal should be taken directly to the Administrative Law Court
(ALC).
The South Carolina Mining Act, in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-30 (Supp. 2005), states that DHEC is responsible for administering the provisions and requirements of the Mining Act, which includes the process and issuance of mining permits.Â  Section 48-20-30 further states that DHEC â€œhas ultimate authority, subject to the appeal provisions of this chapter regulating and controlling such activity.â€Â  (Emphasis added).
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-60 (Supp. 2005), provides that an appeal from a DHEC decision regarding an operating permit may be taken to the Council â€œas provided by Section 48-20-190.â€Â  Section 48-20-190 provides, in pertinent part:

An applicant for a certificate of exploration or operating permit or a person who is aggrieved and is directly affected by the permit may appeal to the council from a decision or determination of the department issuing, refusing, modifying, suspending, revoking, or terminating a certificate of exploration or operating permit or reclamation plan, or imposing a term or condition on the certificate, permit, or reclamation plan.

(Emphasis added).Â  This section further requires the Council to issue a written decision setting forth its findings of fact and conclusions, and authorizes the Council to direct DHEC to take any action necessary to effectuate the Councilâ€™s decision.
Section 48-20-60 states that an appeal from a DHEC decision regarding an operating permit may be taken to the Council as provided by Â§ 48-20-190.Â  This section indicates that any appeal involving a decision goes to the Council, including a decision not to require a permit.
A technical reading of Â§ 48-20-190, however, indicates that respondentsâ€™ appeals should not go to the Council.Â  DHECâ€™s decision did not issue a permit or refuse to issue a permit.Â  Instead, DHECâ€™s decision was a decision that SCE&Gâ€™s project did not require a permit.Â  We conclude, however, that such a technical reading is strained and is not a practical interpretation of Â§ 48-20-190 that is consonant with the purpose and policy of the appeal provisions of the Mining Act.Â  See TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 503 S.E.2d 471 (1998) (statutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers).
Further, we find the legislatureâ€™s intent would not be effectuated by requiring that an appeal from a DHEC decision not to require a permit be taken to the ALC, as opposed to the Council, which the legislature has deemed the appropriate specialized entity for addressing appeals regarding DHECâ€™s interpretation of the Mining Act.Â  See Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 504 S.E.2d 117 (1998) (cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate legislative intent whenever possible).Â  
Accordingly, the Mining Council had subject matter jurisdiction to hear respondentsâ€™ appeals.
II. Appropriate standard of review
In reviewing the Councilâ€™s decision that DHEC should have required SCE&G to obtain a permit, the circuit court applied the substantial evidence standard located in the Administrative Procedures Act (APA), which states that a reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed the circuit court, finding the APA required reviewing courts to apply the substantial evidence standard applicable to appeals from decisions of an administrative agency.
SCE&G argues the APA is not applicable to the instant appeal and that the standard of review located in Title 18, Chapter 7, of the South Carolina Code should have been applied by the lower courts.Â  In support, SCE&G cites S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-200 (Supp. 2005), which states:

An appeal to the courts may be taken from any decision of the council, or its designated committee or the hearing panel, in the manner provided by Chapter 7 of Title 18 [S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 18-7-10 to -300 (1985 & Supp. 2005)].

SCE&G claims this reference means appeals from the Council must be reviewed using the de novo standard of review set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985).[2]
The APA purports to provide uniform procedures before State Boards and Commissions and for judicial review after the exhaustion of administrative remedies.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  We have previously used the APA standard of review when reviewing the appeal of a Mining Council decision.Â  In Waters v. S.C. Land Res. Conservation Commâ€™n, 321 S.C. 219, 467 S.E.2d 913 (1996), the South Carolina Land Resources Conservation Commission (LRCC)[3] granted a corporation a permit to mine kaolin.Â  The Council upheld LRCCâ€™s decision, and the circuit court upheld both determinations.Â  In affirming the Councilâ€™s determination, we specifically identified and applied the substantial evidence standard of review contained in the
APA.
Further, in the analogous case of Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., supra, we ruled the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission) was an agency for purposes of the APA and that the standard of review located in the APA, rather than the standard of review previously applied by the courts in workersâ€™ compensation cases, applied to appeals from the Commission.Â  The Commission and the Mining Council are similar entities.Â  The Commission has seven members who are appointed by the Governor and hears and determines all contested cases involving workersâ€™ compensation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-3-20 (1985).Â  The Council has eleven members, nine of which are appointed by the Governor.Â  The Council hears contested cases involving mining permit decisions made by DHEC.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-21-20 and 48-20-190 (Supp. 2005).Â  In Lark, we held the Commission was an agency for purposes of the APA because it has rule making authority and hears and decides contested matters.Â  The APA defines â€œagencyâ€ as â€œeach state board, commission, department or officer . . . authorized by law to make rules or to determine contested cases.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-310(1) (2005).Â  The Council, like the Commission, falls within this agency definition because it determines contested cases.
We find the courts on appeal should defer to the findings of the Council in these matters given the Council has special expertise on mining that the appellate courts do not possess.Â  Based on the authority of Waters and Lark, we find the APA standard of review applies to appeals from Mining Council decisions.Â  Cf. S.C. Reg. 89-290(H) (Supp. 2005) (all Council hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the APA).
III. Application of appropriate standard of review
SCE&G argues the Court of Appeals erroneously applied the substantial evidence standard to a legal determination, that is whether the project fell within an exception to the permitting requirements, rather than examining this determination for an error of law.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005) (court may reverse or modify decision if substantial rights of appellant have been prejudiced because administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are affected by other error of law).
The Mining Act, which requires a permit for all mining activities, defines â€œminingâ€ as: 

(a) the breaking of the surface soil to facilitate or accomplish the extraction or removal of ores or mineral solids for sale or processing or consumption in the regular operation of a business; 
(b) removal of overburden lying above natural deposits of ore or mineral solids and removal of the mineral deposits exposed, or by removal of ores or mineral solids from deposits lying exposed in their natural state. 
. . . Mining does not include excavation or grading when conducted solely in aid of on-site farming or of on-site construction.Â  . . . 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-40(1) (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).
SCE&Gâ€™s activities on the project included blasting, dewatering, crushing, and stockpiling rock, as well as converting the rock into concrete.Â  All activities were to be performed on SCE&Gâ€™s property.
In reviewing DHECâ€™s determination that SCE&Gâ€™s activities did not require a permit, the Council concluded SCE&Gâ€™s activities constituted mining, did not fit within the on-site construction exception, and that a permit was required.Â  Both the circuit court and the Court of Appeals affirmed, finding substantial evidence existed in the record to support the Councilâ€™s decision that SCE&Gâ€™s project required a permit.
SCE&G argues the lower courts erred by applying the substantial evidence standard of review to the determination of whether the project went beyond the scope of the exception for on-site construction.Â  They argue deference is not required to the Councilâ€™s decision because an interpretation of the requirements of the Mining Act, such as the definition of â€œexcavation,â€ is solely a matter of law.
The question of whether SCE&Gâ€™s activities on the project meet the exception to the permitting requirements carved out by the statute is a mixed question of fact and law.Â  There is a question of law in determining the meaning of the term â€œexcavationâ€ in the exception.Â  See Charleston County Parks & Rec. Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995) (determination of legislative intent is a matter of law); Thompson v. Ford Motor Co., 200 S.C. 393, 21 S.E.2d 34 (1942) (the interpretation of the meaning of a statutory term is not a finding of fact).Â  There is also a question of fact in determining whether SCE&Gâ€™s activities in association with the project exceed the scope of the definition of â€œexcavationâ€ in the exception.
Both the circuit court and the Court of Appeals addressed the definition of excavation, while the Council did not.Â  The Council simply found that SCE&Gâ€™s activities involved more than excavation.Â  The circuit court found that excavating encompasses:Â  (1) forming a cavity or hole in; (2) forming by hollowing out; (3) digging out and removing; and (4) exposing to view by or as if by digging away a covering.Â  The Court of Appeals stated that, while â€œexcavationâ€ was not defined in the statute, the parties had submitted that the literal definition is akin to that of â€œdigging.â€Â  Using the APAâ€™s â€œaffected by an error of lawâ€ standard of review, we find the lower courts did not err in their definition of â€œexcavation.â€
On the issue of whether SCE&Gâ€™s activity is excavation, the appropriate standard of review, as used by the lower courts, is the substantial evidence standard of review.
The Council found SCE&Gâ€™s proposed activities of blasting to create an approximately 60-acre quarry pit, dewatering the quarry pit, producing aggregate from the quarry pit, processing aggregate from the quarry pit using primary and secondary and possibly tertiary crushers and conveyors, stockpiling the crushed aggregate, and further processing the aggregate to create concrete to construct a dam necessitated that SCE&G be required to obtain a mining permit.Â  The Council found these activities involved more than â€œexcavation and gradingâ€ as contemplated by the exception to the permitting requirements.Â  Both the circuit court and the Court of Appeals found there was substantial evidence to support the Councilâ€™s finding that SCE&Gâ€™s project went beyond excavation solely in aid of on-site construction and amounts to mining subject to regulation under the Mining Act.
At the hearing before the Council, Craig Kennedy, the assistant director in the Mining and Solid Waste Management Division of DHEC, testified.Â  He stated the type of projects normally covered by the exception for excavation for on-site construction are for projects where a developer is bringing a site down to a certain grade to allow for construction of a structure, e.g. building a Wal-Mart parking lot, and where a person borrows material from one part of their property to be used on another part of their property.Â  He stated the exception had been used in two cases similar to the instant case and that he interprets the statutory exception to apply anytime the project is solely in aid of on-site construction.Â  Kennedy testified that, without a mining permit, SCE&G will not be required to have a reclamation plan for the land once the project is complete.
James Daniel, the vice-president of Vulcan Materials Company, testified SCE&Gâ€™s activities exceed excavating and grading because the project is being operated like a quarry by engaging in blasting, dewatering, crushing rock, and processing the rock into concrete.
A portion of the Technical Specifications of SCE&Gâ€™s project was introduced at the hearing.Â  The document covered the aggregate production of turning the rock into concrete.Â  The specifications mention the excavation of overburden, blasting, aggregate crushing and handling, dewatering, and creation of concrete that will occur on SCE&Gâ€™s property.Â  The specifications reference the large amounts of equipment that will be involved in the project, such as trucks, conveyors, bins, silos, bulldozers, crushers, a water storage tank, and a plant for mixing the concrete.
From a review of the record, the Councilâ€™s decision finding SCE&Gâ€™s activities constituted mining and did not fall within the statutory exception to the requirement of a mining permit is not clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals did not err by finding there was substantial evidence to support the Councilâ€™s decision. Â Cf. Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 353 S.E.2d 132 (1987) (construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons).
IV. Timeliness of appeals
SCE&G argues respondents, Bursey and the Mining Association (Association), failed to file their appeals to the Council in a timely manner.

Pursuant to the Mining Act,
. . . The person taking the appeal within thirty days after the departmentâ€™s decision shall give written notice to the council through its secretary that he desires to appeal and filing a copy of the notice with the department at the same time.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-190 (Supp. 2005).Â  While this language seems to require that a notice of appeal be filed within thirty days of the actual decision, the Actâ€™s regulations state that the time for giving a notice of appeal does not actually begin to run until the date of notice of the DHEC decision.Â  See 26 S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 89-290(B) (Supp. 2005) (â€œThe person taking the appeal shall within thirty days after notification of the Departmentâ€™s decision, give written notice to the Mining Council through its secretary that he desires to take an appeal, at the same time filing a copy of the notice with the Department.â€) (emphasis added).
DHEC notified SCE&G of its decision that no permit was required by letter dated June 5, 2001.Â  On appeal to the Council, SCE&G argued Bursey and the Associationâ€™s appeals, filed October 17 and October 19, respectively, were untimely because they were filed outside of the thirty-day time period for filing appeals to the Council.Â  Craig Kennedy, of DHEC, testified at the Council hearing that he informed Bursey of DHECâ€™s decision in a telephone conversation before August 31, 2001.Â  Kennedy also testified that he informed the director of the Association of the decision on September 10, and provided a copy of DHECâ€™s written determination to an Association member on September 27, 2001.Â  Kennedy admitted that September 27 was the first time anyone with the Association was provided with a written explanation of the factual and legal basis of DHECâ€™s determination.
Kennedy testified that, as of September 24, the decision not to require a permit was â€œpretty final,â€ but that he could have been overruled by his supervisor at DHEC.Â  He stated, however, that whether to require the permit was his decision to make.
The director of the Association testified he was not aware of the DHEC decision not to require a permit until he received a copy of the written determination on September 27, 2001.
Bursey testified he became aware of DHECâ€™s decision not to require a permit at some point in June 2001.Â  He testified he submitted a Freedom of Information request to DHEC on June 29 requesting any written documentation relating to the decision, but did not receive a response from DHEC until September 26, 2001.Â  Bursey testified that when he did receive a response from DHEC, a written explanation for their decision was not included.Â  Bursey explained he did not receive what he felt to be a credible answer regarding the permitting decision until October 15, 2001, when he was informed by the project manager for SCE&G that no permit would be required because the proposed actions were not â€œmining.â€Â  Prior to that time, Bursey had concluded that DHEC staff had determined SCE&G did not need a permit.Â  At the time he spoke with Kennedy, Bursey testified he was unable to determine if a decision was final.
The Council concluded that DHECâ€™s final decision was not communicated to Bursey or the Association before September 27, 2001, when DHEC provided an Association member with a written copy of the decision.Â  Finding Bursey and the Association did not have notice of DHECâ€™s decision before September 27, 2001, the Council ruled their appeals of October 17 and October 19 were timely filed within the thirty-day period.Â  The circuit court and Court of Appeals affirmed, finding there was substantial evidence to support the Councilâ€™s finding that the appeals were timely filed.
SCE&G argues the evidence in the record establishes that both Bursey and the Association knew of DHECâ€™s final determination long before September 27.
The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an Administrative Agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 461 S.E.2d 388 (1995).Â  Rather, the appellate court need only find,
considering the record as a whole, evidence that would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached.Â  Id. 
We find there is substantial evidence in the record to support the Councilâ€™s decision that respondentsâ€™ appeals were timely filed.Â  While Bursey testified he became aware of DHECâ€™s decision not to require a permit in June 2001, he stated he did not believe this was a final decision made by DHEC, but was a staff decision that could be altered.Â  Kennedyâ€™s testimony that, as of September 24, the decision not to require a permit was â€œpretty final,â€ but was a decision that could have been overruled by his supervisor, supports Burseyâ€™s analysis of the situation.Â  As for the Association, while there was conflicting evidence as to what occurred in a telephone conversation between the Associationâ€™s director and Kennedy on September 10, Kennedy admitted that September 27 was the first time anyone with the Association was provided with a written explanation of DHECâ€™s determination.Â  Further, the director of the Association testified he was unaware of the DHEC decision until he received a copy of the written determination on September 27, 2001.Â  Considering the record as a whole, there is evidence that allows reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the Council reached.Â  See Grant, supra.
Accordingly, the Court of Appeals did not err by affirming the Councilâ€™s decision on the basis there was substantial evidence in the record to support the finding that the appeals were timely filed.
CONCLUSION
We find the Mining Council had subject matter jurisdiction to hear respondentsâ€™ appeals and that the APA standard of review applies to appeals from Mining Council decisions.Â  Further, we find there was substantial evidence to support the Councilâ€™s finding that SCE&Gâ€™s activities constituted mining and did not fall within the statutory exception to the requirement of a mining permit.Â  Finally, we find there was substantial evidence to support the Councilâ€™s finding that the appeals were timely filed.Â  Therefore, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., and WALLER, J., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, the circuit court erred in applying the standard of review found in the Administrative Procedures Act (APA)[4] rather than the de novo standard found in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-7-170 (1985).Â  I would therefore vacate both the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision and the circuit courtâ€™s order and remand for reconsideration of SCE & Gâ€™s appeal.Â Â Â Â  
It is well-settled that a specific statute controls over a more general one, e.g., Capco of Summerville, Inc. v. J.H. Gayle Const. Co., Inc., 368 S.C. 137, 628 S.E.2d 38 (2006), and that a more recent legislative enactment prevails over an earlier one.Â  E.g,, Town of Duncan v. S.C. Budget & Control Bd., 326 S.C. 6, 482 S.E.2d 768 (1997).Â  Here, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-20-200 (Supp. 2005), mandating that appeals from the Mining Council be taken in the manner provided by Â§ 18-7-170, was reenacted after the adoption of the APA, and hence is the more recent statute.Â  Perhaps even more persuasive is the fact that Â§ 48-20-200 is applicable only to Mining Council appeals, and therefore is the more specific statute.Â  Further, the fact that we have applied the APA standard in a previous Mining Council appeal where the parties did not contest the standard of review does not bind us in this case where the matter is properly preserved and presented for our review.Â  E.g., Hutto v. Southern Farm Bureau Life Ins. Co., 259 S.C. 170, 191 S.E.2d 7 (1972) (â€œIt is, of course, settled law that â€˜a case cannot be considered as a binding precedent on a legal point that was not argued in the case and not mentioned in the opinionâ€); cf. Breland v. Love Chevrolet Olds, Inc., 339 S.C. 89, 529 S.E.2d 11 (2000)(fact that Court decided prior appeal on merits is not dispositive whether order is directly appealable where appealability was not raised).
Â  The ordinary rules of statutory construction dictate that the de novo standard be applied.Â  I would therefore vacate the circuit court order and the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision and remand the matter to the circuit court for a de novo appellate review.
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1]The Mining Council is established in the office of the Governor and acts as an advisory body to the Governor in considering issues relating to mining.Â  In addition, the eleven-member Council adjudicates disputes arising from permitting determinations made by DHEC.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 48-21-20 and 48-20-190 (Supp. 2005).
[2]Section 18-7-170 states:Â  â€œ. . . In giving judgment the court may affirm or reverse the judgment of the court below, in whole or in part, as to any or all of the parties and for errors of law and fact.â€ 
[3]Previously, permits were granted or denied by LRCC.Â  Due to government restructuring, the Mining Act is now administered by DHEC.
[4] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e)(2005).

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Petitioner,
v.
Helen Marie Douglas, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Colleton County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26167
Heard April 18, 2006 - Filed June 19, 2006 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,
Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and
Solicitor David M. Pascoe, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Helen Marie Douglas (Respondent) was convicted of the murder and armed robbery of her husband, Rufus â€œRonnieâ€ Douglas (the victim).Â  The Court of Appeals reversed the convictions and remanded the case for a new trial.Â  State v. Douglas, 359 S.C. 187, 597 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s writ of certiorari.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent and the victim owned two houses in Colleton County.Â  Generally, the victim stayed at their home in the town of Walterboro (town house) and Respondent stayed at their house on Chessee Creek (river house).Â  Before 7 a.m. on November 4, 1997, Respondent discovered the victimâ€™s body in a bedroom in the town house. Â An autopsy revealed the victim had been shot five times in the head, including three fatal shots.Â  Â Â 
Police investigators testified the town house appeared ransacked, but there were no signs of a forced entry and nothing was broken.Â  The only item missing was the victimâ€™s wallet.Â  Investigators found five spent shell casings from a .25-caliber pistol on the victimâ€™s bedroom floor. 
According to Respondent, she ate dinner and watched a movie with the victim on November 3.Â  The victim stayed at the town house and Respondent stayed at the river house that night.Â  Respondent originally asserted she did not leave the river house until she went to breakfast at 6 a.m. on November 4.Â  She asserted she went to the town house at 6:50 a.m. to go hunting with the victim.Â  Respondent eventually told police the victim had said during dinner on November 3 he wanted to file for divorce.Â  She also admitted to police she was having an affair, but she denied having any marital problems.
Testimony at trial revealed the victim had plans to go to a car auction with his brother in Ravenel the morning of November 4.Â  Family members also testified Respondent generally did not hunt, and when the victim did hunt, he would go with his grandson.
According to Respondentâ€™s boyfriend, she came to his house about 3:30 a.m. on November 4 and stayed until 5 a.m.Â  She told him the victim had brought up divorce during dinner that night and she was worried because her beauty shop was in the back of the town house.Â  Respondent also told her boyfriend that she planned to work in the yard at the river house on November 4.
Respondent told police the victim owned a .357 Magnum revolver and she owned a .22-caliber derringer. Â Respondent admitted the couple owned a .25-caliber pistol when she was specifically asked by police about the gun.Â  Her sons testified Respondent possessed the coupleâ€™s .25-caliber pistol, and Respondent told police she had returned the pistol to the victim.Â  Respondent also told police she saw the .25-caliber pistol on the victimâ€™s bedside nightstand the Sunday before the murder.Â  
Respondent gave her son, Tony, the keys to the river house after her arrest.Â  Ronald, the coupleâ€™s other son, made a copy of the keys and made at least three trips to the river house between March and April 1998.Â  During one visit to the river house, Ronaldâ€™s ex-wife found a bag with .25-caliber bullets and a box with a receipt for a .25-caliber pistol in a bedroom closet.Â  Ronald turned these items over to the police.Â  
In April 1999, homeowners near the river house discovered a garbage bag in the creek behind their house.Â  The bag contained another garbage bag, rocks, and a brick.Â  The second bag contained five surgical gloves, two shirts, and a pair of jeans.Â  One of Respondentâ€™s daughters-in-law identified the shirts as belonging to Respondent, the jeans as Respondentâ€™s size, and the gloves as similar to those Respondent used at her beauty shop.Â  The only hair sample found on the clothing could not be identified. 
Police also discovered a cinder block in a search of the creek.Â  A .25-caliber pistol, the victimâ€™s wallet, and socks were found inside the cinder block.Â  The pistol was identified as the murder weapon through forensic testing.Â  
The State presented testimony from Eric Creech and Gary Wayne Walker to support its theory that Respondent murdered her husband.Â  During July 1997, Respondent told Creech, who did carpentry work for her, she had a rocky relationship with the victim and they hated each other.Â  When Creech asked Respondent why she did not get out of the marriage, Respondent replied she was scared she might lose some benefits or retirement, but she would stay married. 
Walker testified he had been an acquaintance of the Douglases since the 1970s.Â  One day in September 1997, he saw Respondent by the mailbox at the river house and stopped to talk.Â  He told Respondent he had a new job as an insurance agent and Respondent asked him about several types of insurance.Â  She then told him she was interested in life insurance on the victim and asked Walker to provide her with quotes.Â  Walker testified he saw Respondent at a later date and mentioned the quotes to her, but he never gave any actual quotes to Respondent.Â  
The State introduced evidence that Respondent was the beneficiary of two life insurance policies on the victim.Â  Respondent was the beneficiary of the victimâ€™s federal retirement benefits.Â  After the victimâ€™s death, Respondent submitted claims to receive the benefits under the life insurance policies and the victimâ€™s retirement account.Â  
The jury found Respondent guilty of murder and armed robbery.Â  The trial judge sentenced Respondent to life imprisonment for the murder charge and thirty yearsâ€™ imprisonment for the armed robbery charge, to be served concurrently.Â  
The Court of Appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s denial of Respondentâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  The Court of Appeals further found, however, that the trial court abused its discretion by admitting testimony that Respondent inquired about life insurance on the victim about two months before the murder.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed and granted Respondent a new trial.Â  Douglas, 359 S.C. 196-97, 203-06, 597 S.E.2d at 5-6, 9-11.
ISSUES

  
    
      
         I. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err in finding the trial court abused its discretion by admitting testimony that Respondent casually inquired about obtaining a life insurance policy on the victim two months before his death?Â 
      
      
         II.  
         Did the Court of Appeals err in concluding the admission of the testimony was not harmless error?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed in the absence of a manifest abuse of discretion accompanied by probable prejudice.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002); State v. Frank, 262 S.C. 526, 533, 205 S.E.2d 827, 830 (1974).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law. State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000); State v. Manning, 329 S.C. 1, 7, 495 S.E.2d 191, 194 (1997).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  Admission of Testimony
The State argues the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit testimony from Gary Walker that Respondent inquired about life insurance on the victim approximately two months before the murder.Â  We disagree.
All relevant evidence is admissible.Â  Rule 402, SCRE; State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 127, 551 S.E.2d 240, 247 (2001).Â  Relevant evidence may be excluded where its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991).Â  
Evidence of insurance is properly admitted when it tends to establish motive.Â  State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 311, 513 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999); see also State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 327, 332-33, 468 S.E.2d 626, 629-30 (1996) (evidence that a month before the murder of his wife and son defendant had substantially increased life insurance benefits for them and made himself the beneficiary was some circumstantial evidence of defendantâ€™s motive).Â  Generally, evidence of a life insurance policy is properly admitted when there is evidence of the defendantâ€™s knowledge of the policyâ€™s existence, its validity, or believed validity, and that the defendant will benefit from it.Â  Beckham, 334 S.C. at 311, 513 S.E.2d at 610 (citing State v. Cole, 772 P.2d 531 (Wash. App. 1989)).Â  Our precedent does not necessarily require the existence of a policy, but does require â€œsome showing that the defendant would derive some benefit from the proceeds of the policyâ€ to be admissible.Â  State v. Vermillion, 271 S.C. 99, 100, 245 S.E.2d 128, 129 (1978); see, e.g., State v. Thomas, 159 S.C. 76, 80-81, 156 S.E. 169, 170-71 (1930) (applications for insurance on the life of a boy by his reputed father, which
were refused and on which no policies were issued, were held to be admissible as motive in the prosecution of the father for murdering the boy because they tended to show he tried to obtain an even greater amount of insurance on the life of the deceased than that which he actually procured).
At trial, defense counsel objected to Walkerâ€™s testimony as unfairly prejudicial under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The trial court overruled the objection and allowed the testimony.Â  
The Court of Appeals concluded the trial court abused its discretion by admitting Walkerâ€™s testimony.Â  The Court of Appeals discerned the testimony was not admissible because there was no policy from which Respondent could have received a benefit.Â  The Court of Appeals also found Respondent was prejudiced by the inference that she attempted to purchase life insurance on the victim without his knowledge.Â  Douglas, 359 S.C. at 197, 597 S.E.2d at 6.Â  
Respondentâ€™s inquiry to Walker about life insurance on the victim had only slight probative value because Respondent never received a quote on the premiums, applied for, or purchased life insurance on the victim.Â  Without the existence of an application for a life insurance policy or the issuance of a policy, the evidence presented at trial does not show how Respondent would derive some benefit from the policyâ€™s proceeds.Â  Respondentâ€™s sole inquiry during a casual conversation does not establish motive, planning, or intent.Â  
Moreover, the record reveals Walker did not inform Respondent she would be required to obtain the victimâ€™s permission to purchase the life insurance on him.Â  Walker testified generally that one spouse is required to obtain the other spouseâ€™s permission to be named as a beneficiary under a life insurance policy on the other spouseâ€™s life.Â  The prejudicial effect of this testimony was the inference that Respondent decided not to purchase the life insurance on the victim because she needed the victimâ€™s permission.Â  The slight probative value of Walkerâ€™s testimony did not substantially outweigh the unfair prejudice to Respondent, and the trial court abused its discretion by admitting the testimony.Â  
II. Harmless Error
The State further contends if the trial court improperly admitted Walkerâ€™s testimony, the Court of Appeals erred in finding the error was not harmless.Â  We agree.
Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991).Â  In determining whether an error is harmless, the reviewing court must review the entire record to determine what effect the error had on the verdict.Â  State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 334, 563 S.E.2d 315, 319 (2002).Â  Error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt where it did not contribute to the verdict obtained.Â  Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 172, 420 S.E.2d 834, 842 (1992).Â  Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where â€œguilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.â€Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989).
The police investigation revealed the town house had not been forcibly entered and Respondent was the only person, other than the victim, with a key to the house.Â  Respondent was the last person to see the victim alive and was the first person to discover he had been murdered.Â  Respondent told police she went to the river house on November 4 because she had plans to go hunting with the victim.Â  Yet, she told her boyfriend she planned to do yard work at the river house that day and did not intend to go into town.Â Â  Testimony at trial revealed the victim had plans to go to a car auction that morning.Â  Also, the evidence revealed Respondent was not known to hunt, and if the victim hunted, he went with his grandson; not Respondent.
The night of the victimâ€™s murder, he told Respondent he wanted a divorce.Â  Respondent told police that after returning from dinner with the victim, she did not leave the river house until the next morning when she left for breakfast.Â  However, Respondentâ€™s boyfriend told police she visited him in the early morning hours of November 4.Â  During this visit, Respondent told her boyfriend that the victim wanted a divorce and she was worried about her business if a divorce occurred.Â  Also, Respondent had previously told Creech she hated the victim and she would not divorce him because she did not want to lose her benefits.Â  
Respondent regularly possessed the coupleâ€™s .25-caliber pistol, and the murder weapon was a .25-caliber pistol.Â  The murder weapon and the victimâ€™s wallet were found in the creek behind Respondentâ€™s river house. Respondentâ€™s clothing was found in the creek near the location of the murder weapon and the victimâ€™s wallet.Â  Further, two bullets fired into the victim originated from the same source or same melt of lead as several of the bullets found in the box of ammunition in Respondentâ€™s closet. Â Moreover, the admission of Respondentâ€™s inquiry about life insurance was an insubstantial error given that the State sought to establish motive through the proper admission of two life insurance policies and the victimâ€™s retirement benefits from which Respondent would benefit.Â  The trial courtâ€™s erroneous admission of Walkerâ€™s testimony did not contribute to the verdict obtained and was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding that the trial court abused its discretion by admitting Walkerâ€™s testimony, but we reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding that this was reversible error.Â  The error was harmless and we uphold Respondentâ€™s convictions.Â  
 AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Calvin L. Jeter and Quantilla B. Jeter, Respondents,
v.
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Petitioner,
v.
Phyllis P. Brown, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26168Â Â 
Heard March 9, 2006 - Filed June 19, 2006 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Andrew F. Lindemann, of Davidson, Morrison and Lindemann, P.A., of Columbia; and Charles V. Verner, of Harley and Verner, L.L.P, of Newberry, for Petitioner.
Albert V. Smith, of Spartanburg, for Respondents Calvin L. Jeter and Quantilla Jeter. 
Daryl G. Hawkins, of Columbia; and Howard Hammer, of Hammer and Hammer, of Columbia, for Respondent Phyllis P. Brown.
      
    
  


 ACTING JUSTICE COUCH:Â  This Court granted South Carolina Department of Transportationâ€™s (SCDOT) writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ rulings on subject matter jurisdiction and venue in Jeter v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 358 S.C. 528, 595 S.E.2d 827 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 12, 1997, Calvin Jeter was operating a motorcycle on Secondary Road 37, also known as Herbert Road, in Union County, and Phyllis Brown was driving a vehicle in the opposite direction.Â  SCDOT had recently resurfaced part of Herbert Road.Â  After entering upon a resurfaced portion of the road, Brown saw a deer on the roadside and applied the brakes.Â  She lost control of her vehicle and collided with Jeterâ€™s motorcycle.Â  Brown claimed excessive, loose gravel on the road caused her to lose control of the vehicle. 
Jeter and his wife, Quantilla, each filed complaints in the Union County Court of Common Pleas against SCDOT under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act (SCTCA).[1]Â  The Jeters alleged SCDOT had failed to safely maintain the roadway and failed to warn drivers of its dangerous condition.Â  
SCDOT filed third-party complaints against Brown, naming her as a third-party defendant.Â  SCDOT contended Brown was a necessary party to the litigation to permit apportionment of fault under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(c).[2]Â  Brown filed a counterclaim against SCDOT under the SCTCA for personal injuries she sustained from the accident.Â  
After settling with the Jeters, Brown moved to dismiss the third-party complaints under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The lower court ruled Brown was a necessary party to the action under Rule 19, SCRCP, and must remain a party to the action solely for the purposes of satisfying the statutory requirement of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(c).
Brown then filed an amended answer and counterclaim, alleging venue in Union County was improper and that as a matter of right should be transferred to Fairfield County, her county of residence.Â  Brown subsequently filed a motion to change venue to Fairfield County.Â  The lower court granted Brownâ€™s motion, over SCDOTâ€™s objection, and transferred venue to Fairfield County.Â  The lower court subsequently denied SCDOTâ€™s motion to change venue back to Union County, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(b).Â  
During the trial, the lower court ruled Brown was not negligent as a matter of law and granted a directed verdict for Brown on the issue of her negligence.Â  The lower court also granted Brownâ€™s motion for directed verdict on SCDOTâ€™s defense of unavoidable accident. Â The jury returned verdicts in favor of the Jeters and Brown.Â  
SCDOT appealed to the Court of Appeals.Â  The Court of Appeals interpreted S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(b) to establish subject matter jurisdiction in the circuit court of South Carolina and venue in the county where the act or omission occurred.Â  The Court of Appeals found the lower court did not abuse its discretion by transferring venue to Fairfield County under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (2005).Â  The Court of Appeals further found the lower court erred in directing a verdict for Brown on the issue of her negligence because the SCTCA requires the jury to apportion fault among all potential tortfeasors.Â  Accordingly, the Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the case.Â  Jeter, 358 S.C. at 532-36, 595 S.E.2d at 829-31.[3]
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err in construing S.C. Code
          Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(b)?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the Court of Appeals err in finding the lower court did not
          abuse its discretion by transferring venue to Fairfield County under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30?Â 
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Motions to change the venue of a trial are addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Garrett v. Packet Motor Express Co., 263 S.C. 463, 210 S.E.2d 912 (1975).Â  This Court will not disturb the trial judgeâ€™s decision on appeal unless a manifest abuse of discretion is found resulting in an error of law.Â  Graham v. Beverly, 235 S.C. 222, 110 S.E.2d 923 (1959). Moreover, the error of law must be so opposed to the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion as to amount to a deprivation of the legal rights of the party. Oâ€™Shields v. Caldwell, 208 S.C. 245, 37 S.E.2d 665 (1946).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Construction of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-100(b)
SCDOT argues the Court of Appeals erred in finding Â§ 15-78-100(b) is not a statutory provision solely setting forth subject matter jurisdiction.Â  SCDOT argues this statutory provision provides that only the circuit court in the county where the act or omission occurred has subject matter jurisdiction over an action brought pursuant to the SCTCA.Â  Accordingly, the only court having subject matter jurisdiction over this particular case is the Union County Court of Common Pleas.Â  We disagree.
The issue of interpretation of a statute is a question of law for the court.Â  Charleston County Parks & Rec. Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 459 S.E.2d 841 (1995) (holding the determination of legislative intent is a matter of law).Â  This Court is free to decide questions of law with no particular deference to the lower court.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000).
The Court of Appeals held Â§ 15-78-100(b) addressed subject matter jurisdiction to the extent that such jurisdiction was conferred in the circuit court.Â  The Court of Appeals further held the statutory provision established venue in the county in which the act or omission occurred.Â  Jeter, 358 S.C. at 532-33, 595 S.E.2d at 829-30.Â  Â 
Subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  Venue is the place or geographical location of trial.Â  The propriety of either is independent of the other. Â Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 236, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994); State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The South Carolina Constitution in Article V, Â§ 11, states, â€œThe Circuit Court shall be a general trial court with original jurisdiction in civil and criminal cases, except those cases in which exclusive jurisdiction shall be given to inferior courts, and shall have such appellate jurisdiction as provided by law.â€[4]Â  Section 15-78-100(b) states, â€œJurisdiction for any action brought under this chapter is in the circuit court and brought in the county in which the act or omission occurred.â€
In Dove, Dove appealed a workerâ€™s compensation claim to the circuit court, which dismissed his appeal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  On appeal, the Court construed S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-60 (Supp. 1993), which
provided in relevant part: â€œ[E]ither party . . . may appeal from the decision of the commission to the court of common pleas of the county in which the alleged accident happened, or in which the employer resides or has his principal office.â€Â  Dove, 314 S.C. at 238, 442 S.E.2d at 600.Â  The Court discerned, â€œThere is but one Circuit Court in South Carolina, with uniform subject matter jurisdiction â€˜throughout the State.â€™â€Â  Id. (citing State ex rel. Riley v. Martin, 274 S.C. 106, 111, 262 S.E.2d 404, 406 (1980); S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 1) (emphasis in original).Â  Then, the Court construed the statutory provision as granting subject matter jurisdiction to the court of common pleas throughout the state and as designating venue in the county in which the alleged accident happened or in which the employer resides or has his principal office.Â  Id. at 239, 442 S.E.2d at 600. 
In Harrison v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 261 S.C. 302, 199 S.E.2d 763 (1973), overruled on other grounds by McCall by Andrews v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985), superseded by statute, the Court considered whether S.C. Code Â§ 10-2605 (1962),[5] was intended to confer subject matter jurisdiction or was a venue provision.Â  Former section 10-2605 provided in pertinent part: â€œThe circuit courts of this State are hereby vested with jurisdiction to hear and determine all questions, actions and controversies, . . . affecting boards, commissions and agencies of this State, and officials of the State in their official capacities [i]n the circuit where such question, action or controversy shall arise.â€ Â Harrison, 261 S.C. at 305, 199 S.E.2d at 764 (emphasis in original).Â  The Court found because the South Carolina Constitution granted subject matter jurisdiction to the court of common pleas in all civil cases, â€œthe [statute] could not have been intended to confer jurisdiction on it of this class of actions in the strict sense of that term.Â  The intent of the legislature must have been to fix the venue of such actions â€˜in the circuit where such question, action or controversy shall arise. . . .â€™ â€ Id. at 306, 199 S.E.2d at 764.
Section 15-78-100(b) is similar to Â§ 42-17-60 and former Â§ 10-2605 in that the statutory provision references subject matter jurisdiction and venue in one sentence.Â  Because there is but one circuit court in South Carolina, with uniform subject matter jurisdiction throughout the state, Â§ 15-78-100(b) establishes subject matter jurisdiction for actions arising under the SCTCA in the circuit court throughout the state.Â  See Dove, 314 S.C. at 238, 442 S.E.2d at 600; Riley, 274 S.C. at 111, 262 S.E.2d at 406.Â  Section 15-78-100(b) also establishes venue â€œin the county in which the act or omission occurred.â€Â  See also Ellis by Ellis v. Oliver, 307 S.C. 365, 367, 415 S.E.2d 400, 401 (1992) (â€œUnder the SCTCA, venue is proper where the act or omission occurred.â€). 
II. Transfer of venue pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30
SCDOT argues if Â§ 15-78-100(b) establishes venue in the county in which the act or omission occurred, then the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the lower courtâ€™s transfer of venue under Â§ 15-7-30 when the original venue was proper under Â§ 15-78-100(b). Â We agree.[6]
Upon Brownâ€™s motion, the lower court transferred venue to Fairfield County as a matter of right, citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30;[7] McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 479 S.E.2d 67 (Ct. App. 1996); and Ellis, 307 S.C. at 365, 415 S.E.2d at 400.[8]Â  
The Court of Appeals found that Â§ 15-78-100(b) did not prevent the lower court from considering Brownâ€™s motion to transfer venue pursuant to Â§ 15-7-30.Â  The Court of Appeals further found the lower court did not abuse its discretion by transferring venue to Brownâ€™s county of residence.Â  Jeter, 358 S.C. at 533, 595 S.E.2d at 829-30.Â  
The defendant has a substantial right to be tried in the county of his residence pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-7-30 (2005).Â  Thus, in a case involving only one defendant or multiple defendants who reside in a single county, the venue choice generally is controlled by the residence of the defendant.Â  Carroll, 302 S.C. at 177, 394 S.E.2d at 708.Â  However, where there are multiple defendants residing in different counties, the plaintiff may properly bring the action in the county where any one of the defendants resides at the time of the commencement of the action.Â  Â In such a case, the plaintiff ordinarily has the right of election as to the county in which an action will be brought.Â  Mack v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 245 S.C. 619, 623-24, 142 S.E.2d 50, 53 (1965); Rankin Lumber Co. v. Graveley, 112 S.C. 128, 99 S.E. 349 (1919).Â  
â€œWhere an action is properly commenced in any one of two or more venues and is properly brought in one of such venues, it is removable to the other proper venue only if there exists some statutory ground for removal other than the bringing of suit in the wrong venue.â€ Â 92A C.J.S. Venue Â§ 157 (2000); see also 77 Am.Jur.2d Venue Â§ 67 (1997); Slattery v. Iowa Dist. Ct. for Johnson County, 442 N.W.2d 82 (Iowa 1989); Kahn v. Gill Hills Co., 610 So.2d 1374 (Fla. App. 1992).Â  â€œThe general rule is that where an action is properly instituted in a county other than that of the defendantâ€™s residence, a defendant has no right to request a change of venue to the county of his or her residence on the ground that the action was not brought in a proper county, even if the action could also have been commenced in the county where the defendant resides.â€ Â 92A C.J.S. Venue Â§ 163; see also Tribolet v. Fowler, 266 P.2d 1088 (Ariz. 1954).
We find the reasoning of the Court of Appeals erroneous.Â  The Jeters properly instituted their actions against SCDOT by filing their actions in the Union County Court of Common Pleas pursuant to Â§ 15-78-100(b).Â  Because the actions were properly instituted, Brown, as a defendant, had no right to request a change of venue to the county of her residence based on an allegation that the actions were brought in an improper venue.[9] Â Thus, the lower court abused its discretion by transferring venue to Brownâ€™s county of residence pursuant to Â§ 15-7-30. Â Â Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We affirm the Court of Appealsâ€™ finding that Â§ 15-78-100(b) establishes subject matter jurisdiction in the circuit court of South Carolina and venue in the county where the act or omission occurred.Â  We find the lower court abused its discretion by transferring venue under Â§ 15-7-30 and reverse that part of the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â  Further, we find it unnecessary to address SCDOTâ€™s remaining arguments and issue on appeal related to venue.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issues is
dispositive). 
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 through -200 (2005).
[2]Â  Section 15-78-100(c) provides:
In all actions brought pursuant to this chapter when an alleged
tortfeasor is named as party defendant in addition to the governmental Â Â Â Â Â Â  entity, the trier of fact must return a special verdict specifying the proportion of monetary liability of each defendant against whom
liability is determined.
[3] Â The Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling to reverse the directed verdict for Brown on the issue of her negligence and its decision to not reach the issue of whether the trial court should have charged the defense of unavoidable accident have not been appealed.Â  Because these rulings have gone unchallenged, they are the law of the case.Â  See Clark v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 608 S.E.2d 573 (2005) (an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal). 
[4] Â See also S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 1 (â€œThe judicial power shall be vested in a unified judicial system, which shall include a Supreme Court, a Court of Appeals, a Circuit Court, and such other courts of uniform jurisdiction as may be provided for by general law.â€).Â  
[5] Â Currently codified at Â§ 15-77-50 (2005).Â  See also Whetstone v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Hwys. & Pub. Transp., 272 S.C. 324, 252 S.E.2d 35 (1979) (concluding Â§ 15-77-50 established venue).
[6]Â Â  Regardless of any preservation problems we address this issue in the interest of judicial economy. Â The first time this case was tried, it ended in a mistrial.Â  This appeal involves the second trial, and based on the unappealed rulings of the Court of Appeals, this case will be tried for a third time. Â See S. Bell Tel. & Tel. Co. v. Hamm, 306 S.C. 70, 75, 409 S.E.2d 775, 778 (1991) (deciding an issue on appeal in the interest of
judicial economy). 
[7] Â Section 15-7-30 then provided: 
In all other cases the action shall be tried in the county in which
the defendant resides at the time of the commencement of the action.Â  If there be more than one defendant then the action may
be tried in any county in which one or more of the defendants to such action resides at the time of the commencement of the
action.Â  If none of the parties shall reside in the State the action may be tried in any county which the plaintiff shall designate in
his complaint.Â  This section is subject however to the power of the court to change the place of trial in certain cases as provided
by law.Â Â  
â€œIn all other casesâ€ has been interpreted to mean Â§Â§ 15-7-10 and -20.Â  See Carroll v. Guess, 302 S.C. 175, 177, 394 S.E.2d 707, 708 (1990);
Royster Co. v. E. Distrib., Inc., 301 S.C. 18, 20, 389 S.E.2d 863, 864 (1990).Â  The 2005 amendments to Â§ 15-7-30 are not applicable to this case.Â  See Â§ 15-7-30 (Supp. 2005) (applicable to causes of action arising on or after July 1, 2005).
[8]Â  Although the parties argue otherwise, Ellis is not applicable to the current case.Â  The issue in Ellis was whether three defendants were considered multiple defendants for the purpose of determining venue when three separate actions were consolidated under Rule 42, SCRCP.Â  In this case, the issue is whether venue may be transferred under Â§ 15-7-30 when the plaintiffs instituted their actions in a proper venue under Â§ 15-78-100(b).

[9] Â This opinion does not preclude the parties from bringing a subsequent motion pursuant to Â§ 15-7-100 to change venue based on the convenience of witnesses and the promotion of justice.Â  Such a motion would be left to the discretion of the lower court.Â  Chestnut v. Reid, 299 S.C. 305, 307, 384 S.E.2d 713, 714 (1989).

title: Seabrook v. Knox
description: This case deals with due process and equal protection challenges to the actions of the City of Folly Beach regarding the zoning of an unusual tract of land on Folly Island.  The trial court held that the City of Folly Beach denied the due process and equal protection rights of Edward M. Seabrook and Folly North Partners.  The Supreme Court reversed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Edward M. Seabrook, Jr., and Folly North Partners, LLC,
Respondents,
v.
Vernon Knox, Gered Lennon, Wallace Benson, and Allen Boyd, in their official capacities as members of the City Council of the City of Folly Beach, and Harvey
Wittschen, Ernest Horres, Victoria Messina, and John Ball, in their official capacities as members of the Zoning Board of Adjustment of the City of Folly Beach, and Tom Hall, in his official capacity as the Building/Zoning Official of the City of Folly Beach, and The City of Folly Beach,
Defendants,
of whom The City of Folly Beach is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26169
Heard January 18, 2006 - Filed June 19, 2006Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Christopher L. Murphy and James A. Stuckey, Jr., both of Stuckey Law Offices, of Charleston, for Appellant.
William B. Regan and Frances I. Cantwell, both of Reagan and Cantwell, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  The trial court held that the City of Folly Beach (City) denied the due process and equal protection rights of Edward M. Seabrook and Folly North Partners (collectively Respondents) as guaranteed by the United States Constitution.Â  This case was certified from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We reverse.Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
This suit is based on the conduct of the City of Folly Beach, the Folly Beach City Council (City Council), and Folly Beachâ€™s local zoning authorities concerning a parcel of property owned by Seabrook.Â  In 1996, Seabrook sold Folly North Partners (Folly North) an option to buy an undeveloped tract of land on the east end of Folly Island.Â  The option was contingent on the property being zoned for residential use because Folly North hoped to develop the property into oceanfront lots.Â  
Immediately, problems arose regarding the propertyâ€™s zoning.Â  Because the Seabrook property was located at the east end of the island, it bordered only a former United States Coast Guard Base and the water.Â  Most likely, the propertyâ€™s location led to the current confusion and dispute, since it appears most people mistakenly believed the Coast Guard owned the entire east end of the island.Â  The zoning problems immediately arose because the official map accompanying the last zoning ordinance, passed in 1993, stopped at the beginning of the Coast Guard Base and illustrated that all land beyond the baseâ€™s boundary was zoned N-1 (nature conservancy).Â  
This ambiguity came to light when L. Russell Bennett, the principal owner of Folly North, began discussing his plans to develop a residential subdivision on the property.Â  Bennett testified he â€œreserved his rightsâ€ as to the then existing zoning, and took the matter to the City Council. 
Bennett first appeared before the City Council in May of 1996, at which time he presented an ordinance to rezone the Seabrook property from N-1 to R-1 (residential). Â The City Council passed the rezoning ordinance on first reading, but on the second reading, the ordinance failed.Â  Later, the City held a citywide referendum, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-17-10 (2004), to rezone the Seabrook property from N-1 to R-1.Â  The referendum failed as well.Â  
In November of 1996, Bennett submitted a preliminary plat for subdivision of the Seabrook property to the city building official, Tom Hall.Â  By letter, Hall refused to accept the plat because the Seabrook property was zoned N-1.Â  Bennett appealed to the zoning board, arguing the Seabrook property was never zoned N-1 because it did not appear on the 1993 zoning map.Â  The zoning board upheld the building officialâ€™s determination.Â  Bennett appealed the zoning boardâ€™s decision to circuit court.
The circuit court reversed the zoning boardâ€™s decision.Â  The circuit court based this decision on a 1979 zoning map showing the Seabrook property as zoned R-2 (moderate density residential district).Â  The circuit court concluded that because the 1993 ordinance map did not â€œshow, delineate, describe or otherwise referenceâ€ the Seabrook property, and because neither the planning commission nor the City Council could demonstrate they intended to rezone the property in 1993, the Seabrook property retained its residential zoning classification and was never rezoned to N-1.Â  After the trial courtâ€™s decision, Bennett resubmitted his plat application which was eventually approved. [1]
Respondents filed the instant action in the court of common pleas. Respondents alleged depravations of procedural and substantive due process, a violation of equal protection, gross negligence, and a temporary taking.Â  Prior to trial, all defendants except the City were dismissed, and all causes of action except due process and equal protection were abandoned.Â  Specifically, Respondents alleged: (1) that the City deprived Respondents of their â€œvested interestâ€ in having their plat approved by improperly developing an â€œofficial policyâ€ that the Seabrook property should be zoned N-1, and (2) that Respondents were members of a class of owners of property zoned R-1, but were arbitrarily treated different from all other members of the class.Â  
The trial court found the City violated Respondentsâ€™ rights to due process and equal protection.Â  The trial court found the City Council usurped the building officialâ€™s authority to enforce the zoning ordinance by adopting an â€œofficial policyâ€ that the Seabrook property was zoned N-1.Â  The trial court found this was a deprivation of due process because it obstructed the building officialâ€™s ability to offer an unbiased opinion as to the propertyâ€™s zoning and deprived Respondents of the right to have their subdivision plat processed.Â  As to equal protection, the trial court found Respondentsâ€™ rights were violated when the City Council zoned Respondentsâ€™ property without following the legislative process.Â  
This case was certified to this Court from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and the City raises the following issue for review:

Did the City deny Respondentsâ€™ rights to due process and equal protection as guaranteed by the United States Constitution?

Law/Analysis
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless they are not reasonably supported by the evidence.Â  Townes Associates, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 774 (1976). 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Due Process


In its decision finding a due process violation, the trial court made no distinction between substantive and procedural due process.Â  Because
 the City divides its argument between substantive due process and procedural due process, we address the issues in a similar manner.
A. Procedural Due Process


â€œProcedural due process imposes constraints on governmental decisions which deprive individuals of â€˜libertyâ€™ or â€˜propertyâ€™ interests within the meaning of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth or Fourteenth Amendment.â€Â  Matthews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 332 (1976). Â In this case, Respondents allege they possessed a vested property interest in having their plat application approved and in the immediate use of their property for development of a subdivision.Â  We dismiss this claim as moot.Â  Â Â Â 
A moot case exists where a judgment rendered by the court will have no practical legal effect upon an existing controversy because an intervening event renders any grant of effectual relief impossible for the reviewing court.Â  Mathis v. S. C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973).Â  Â If there is no actual controversy, this Court will not decide moot or academic questions.Â  Id. (citing Jones v. Dillon-Marion Human Res. Dev. Commâ€™n., 277 S.C. 533, 535, 291 S.E.2d 195, 196 (1982)).Â  
Two factors compel our finding Respondentsâ€™ procedural due process claim is moot.Â  First, this is not an appropriate case to award money damages under the guise of a procedural due process violation.Â  A violation of a plaintiffâ€™s procedural due process rights is typically remedied by either injunctive relief or a court order instructing that the plaintiff be afforded the process he was denied.Â  In this case, since Respondents seek relief in the form of money damages, ruling on a procedural due process claim would have no practical effect whatsoever.
Second, because the Seabrook property was rezoned and because Respondentsâ€™ plat was approved, Respondents have already received the appropriate procedural relief.Â  Respondents claim the City Council developed an â€œofficial policyâ€ that the Seabrook property would be zoned N-1, thereby depriving Respondents of the process set out in the Cityâ€™s ordinances for determining zoning disputes.Â  As a result, Respondentsâ€™ claim they were prevented from having their subdivision plat approved.Â  We disagree.Â  
Respondentsâ€™ position is best stated as claiming not that they were deprived of the process set by the law, but that the process set out in the law was tainted by City Councilâ€™s â€œofficial position.â€Â  The claim that the process was â€œtaintedâ€ is more akin to a substantive due process claim because at no time were Respondents prevented from going through the dispute resolution procedure. Â In fact, it was in the final stage of this procedure, appeal in the circuit court, that Respondents won their desired result. Â Since Respondentsâ€™ plat was approved, thereby purging any continuing â€œtaintâ€ in the process, any judgment on the issue of procedural due process would be a speculative and academic exercise.Â  For this reason, we reverse the trial court and find Respondentsâ€™ procedural due process claim is moot.Â  
B. Substantive Due Process
Substantive due process protects a person from being deprived of life, liberty, or property for arbitrary reasons.Â  Worsley Companies, Inc. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 339 S.C. 51, 56, 528 S.E.2d 657, 660 (2000).Â  To establish a substantive due process claim, a plaintiff must show he possessed a constitutionally protected property interest that was deprived by state action so far beyond the limits of legitimate governmental action, no process could cure the deficiency.Â  Sylvia Dev. Corp. v. Calvert County, 48 F.3d 810, 827 (4th Cir. 1998).Â  
The trial court found the Cityâ€™s actions were an unprecedented and arbitrary interference with the process of resolving zoning disputes and Respondentsâ€™ right to have their subdivision plat processed.Â  We find Respondentsâ€™ substantive due process claim is barred by a previously executed waiver.
After the original trial court determined the Seabrook property was zoned for residential use, Bennett asked the zoning official to approve his plat.Â  After some delay in assembling the proper documents,[2] the plat was approved, but with several â€œconditions.â€Â  Specifically, the plat approval contained three limitations and contingencies regarding erosion on the coastline of the property.Â  Respondents sued the City in an attempt to have these conditions removed, and Respondents were granted summary judgment.Â  The City appealed.
While the case was pending in this Court, the parties settled the lawsuit.Â  The release executed in the settlement discharged the City from:

any and all known or unknown injuries, damages, loss of services, loss of profits, loss of income, expenses, compensation, rights, suits of whatever kind and natureâ€¦on account of, arising out of or in any way growing out of, the subdivision of the tract of property on the north end of Folly Beach commonly referred to as â€œThe Seabrook Tract,â€ . . . .

(emphasis added).
In the instant lawsuit, Respondentsâ€™ complaint alleges they had a â€œvested property interestâ€ in having their plat approved and â€œto the immediate use of their property for the development of a nine (9) lot residential subdivision.â€Â  Because Respondentsâ€™ due process claims are based upon the Cityâ€™s refusal to immediately approve Respondentsâ€™ plat for subdivision, the previously signed release is directly implicated.Â  
In ruling the earlier release did not apply, the trial court incorrectly reasoned that the release applied only to the case at that time pending in this Court.Â  The language of the release clearly indicates it applies more broadly. Â Specifically, the release applies to all claims â€œon account of, arising out of or in any way growing out of, the subdivision of the tract of property.â€Â  The release does provide that these circumstances are â€œmore fully delineatedâ€ in the case at that time pending before this Court; however, the trial court improperly distinguished the instant case by stating â€œ[t]he case now before the court is not based on the actions of City officials in refusing to subdivide the Seabrook Tract, rather, it is based on the actions of City officials in adopting and implementing a policy establishing zoning outside the process set by law.â€ Â (emphasis in original). 
This purported distinction ignores the plain language of Respondentsâ€™ complaint.Â  The complaint expressly rests the due process claims on the obstruction of Respondentsâ€™ right to subdivide the Seabrook tract.Â  For these reasons, we reverse the trial court and find Respondentsâ€™ substantive due process claim is waived.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Equal Protection
To establish an equal protection violation, plaintiffs must demonstrate they were intentionally and purposely subjected to treatment different from others similarly situated.Â  Sylvia Dev. Corp., 48 F.3d at 818.Â  The trial court found the City treated Respondents differently from similarly situated property owners and that the City imposed a zoning designation on Respondentsâ€™ property outside the legislative process.Â  We dismiss this claim as moot.Â  
A case becomes moot when the parties no longer possess a cognizable interest in the outcome.Â  Powell v. McCormack, 395 U.S. 486, 496 (1969).Â  The record indicates that the Seabrook property was rezoned after a slight delay in the process, and that Respondents ultimately sold the property for a sum comparable with the value of residential oceanfront property.Â  As Respondents no longer possess any claim to the property, were not delayed significantly in this process, and realized such substantial financial gains, any claim to an equal protection violation is far too tenuous for adjudication.Â  
That we dispose of this case on somewhat technical grounds should not be perceived as a license for a city or municipal authority to use last-minute rezoning to cure violations of a property ownerâ€™s rights in hopes of seeking shelter in the principles of justiciability.Â  When established zoning statutes and procedures are arbitrarily or unreasonably disregarded, several constitutional claims may arise.Â  In this case, however, any judgment of this Court on equal protection grounds would clearly lack a practical effect.Â Â  Â Â 
Conclusion
The trial court erred in finding violations of Respondentsâ€™ due process and equal protection rights.Â  We are extremely mindful of the often contentious nature of zoning and development disputes, and we recognize that, in the appropriate cases, improper actions of local administrative bodies may result in federal due process and equal protection violations.Â  
Ultimately, our conclusion in this case is compelled by two factors:Â  first, the fact that Respondents achieved a beneficial result after proceeding through the very process the law guaranteed; second, the fact that much of this subject matter was waived in the disposition of a previous lawsuit.
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse.
 MOORE, and BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice Clyde N. Davis, concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

[1]Although their plat was approved, Respondents never actually developed the Seabrook property.Â  In fact, after executing its option and purchasing the property for $500,000.00, Folly North sold the property to the Charleston County Parks and Recreation Commission for $3,956,524.01.Â  Folly North also obtained a $2,200,000.00 tax credit to defer tax on the capital gains realized by the sale.Â  
[2] This delay was initially attributable to a dispute about whether the City was in possession of a valid plat application and whether Respondents needed to re-submit the plat application.Â  Once this issue was resolved, concern on the City Council about conditioning the platâ€™s approval on the satisfaction of several measures aimed at erosion control delayed the process further.Â
