Appellant alleged the trial court committed errors in limiting voir dire, in admitting improper evidence, and in allowing the solicitor to improperly inject racial issues into the trial.   The Court disagreed and affirmed Appellantâ€™s death sentence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Johnny O'Landis Bennett, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26174
Heard April 4, 2006 - Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek and Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Claire, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, and Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is an appeal from a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  Appellant contends the trial court committed three errors warranting reversal.Â  First, the trial court refused to allow defense counsel to ask jurors whether they would â€œstick with their vote or go with the majorityâ€ during voir dire.Â  Second, the trial court determined that certain testimony and evidence about a prior offense was not inadmissible â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence.Â  Third, the trial court ruled that remarks made by the Solicitor did not unfairly inject racial issues into the trial.Â  We affirm.
Factual/Procedural Background
Appellant received several criminal convictions in connection with the murder of Benton Smith (Victim).Â  The evidence established that Victim was last seen leaving his residence accompanied by Appellant.Â  After police and family members searched for Victim for several days, Appellant led police to Victimâ€™s body which was buried under wood brush behind Appellantâ€™s sisterâ€™s home.Â  Victim had been stabbed approximately seventy (70) times with a Phillips head screwdriver and died as a result of internal bleeding.Â  Appellant gave conflicting statements to police; first denying any knowledge of Victimâ€™s murder, then confessing to the murder, and finally recanting and maintaining his innocence.Â  After a sentencing proceeding, the jury sentenced Appellant to death.
This Court affirmed Appellantâ€™s convictions but reversed his death sentence.Â  State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 493 S.E.2d 845 (1997).Â  During Appellantâ€™s second sentencing proceeding, he objected to (1) the trial courtâ€™s decision to exclude a question from voir dire, (2) the introduction of testimony and evidence regarding a prior conviction for assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN), and (3) comments made by the Solicitor during cross-examination of a witness and during closing arguments.
Specifically, Appellant alleged the trial court improperly excluded the â€œwill you go with the majority or hold to your decisionâ€ question from voir dire.Â  The trial court found that the question tended to suggest the possibility of a hung jury and â€œthe fact that [the juror] can hold things up.â€Â  The court held that the defense could ask a juror â€œif they understand that by their oath that [sic] they should make their own determinations of the facts . . . but certainly we cannot get into pitting them against the other jurors.â€Â  Id.Â  
Additionally, Appellant alleged that the trial court allowed the mothers of the two ABHAN victims to present impermissible â€œvictim impactâ€ testimony, that the trial court improperly admitted highly prejudicial hospital photographs of the two ABHAN victims, and that the trial court improperly allowed one of the ABHAN victims to testify about a dream he had in which â€œblack Indiansâ€ were chasing him.Â  The trial court determined that the testimony and photographs were relevant to Appellantâ€™s character and admissible as details of prior criminal convictions.Â  Also, the trial court noted that the â€œblack Indiansâ€ comment was mentioned only once, was not elicited by the State, and did not prejudice Appellant.Â  
Furthermore, Appellant alleged that the Solicitor improperly injected racial issues into the sentencing proceeding by making inappropriate comments while questioning a witness.Â  While cross-examining a witness about a former prison guard who had engaged in a sexual relationship with Appellant, the witness asked the Solicitor, â€œYou mean the big girl?â€Â  The Solicitor responded, â€œYou know, the blond lady?â€Â  The trial court found that this reference did not improperly inject race into the trial.Â  
Finally, Appellant alleged that the Solicitor attempted to inject racial issues into the sentencing proceeding by making inappropriate remarks during the Stateâ€™s closing arguments.Â  In his closing arguments, the Solicitor compared Appellantâ€™s size and violent acts to those of â€œKing Kongâ€ and a â€œCaveman.â€Â  Appellant first objected to these comments in his motion for a new trial, and the trial court determined that these comments properly described the circumstances surrounding the murder, Appellantâ€™s character and violent background, his disregard for prison rules, his size, strength, and destructiveness, and were invited responses to Appellantâ€™s mitigating evidence and argument.Â  
This appeal followed, and Appellant raises the following issues for review:

  
    
      
        I.
         Did the trial court err in excluding the â€œwill you go with the majorityâ€ question from voir dire?Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in admitting certain evidence regarding Appellantâ€™s prior ABHAN conviction?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        III. 
         Did the Solicitorâ€™s comments during cross-examination of a witness or during closing arguments improperly inject racial issues into the trial?
      
    
  

Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Voir Dire
Appellant argues that the trial court improperly excluded the â€œwill you go with the majorityâ€ question from voir dire.Â  We disagree.
In general, both the scope of voir dire and the manner in which it is conducted are within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Hill, 361 S.C. 297, 308, 604 S.E.2d 696, 702 (2004).Â  â€œTo constitute reversible error, a limitation on questioning must render the trial â€˜fundamentally unfair.â€™â€Â  Id.
Our opinion in State v. Hill controls on this issue.Â  In Hill, the trial court refused to allow the defense to ask jurors whether they would â€œgive up their vote in order to go with the majority.â€Â  Id. at 308, 604 S.E.2d at 702.Â  Hill argued that this was improper because our opinion reversing Appellantâ€™s death sentence condoned the use of the â€œgo with the majorityâ€ question.Â  Id.Â  Disagreeing, this court clarified that we reversed Appellantâ€™s death sentence because the trial court improperly qualified and seated a juror who answered that he would indeed â€œgo with the majorityâ€ over his own determination.Â  Id. at 309, 604 S.E.2d at 702.Â  Ultimately, this Court held that a review of entire voir dire indicated that Hillâ€™s jurors were unbiased, impartial, and capable of following the instructions on the law.Â  Id. at 310, 604 S.E.2d at 702.Â  Relying on the highly deferential standard of review in voir dire cases, we stated: 

[W]hat is constitutionally mandated is the selection of a fair and impartial jury.Â  No particular formula of questions is mandated to achieve this goal.Â  In our justice system, the trial judge has the discretion and the duty to monitor the voir dire so as to ensure that the jury selected measures up to the constitutional standard.Â  The judgeâ€™s ruling in this case, disallowing defense counsel to question jurors about their propensity to go with the majority, did not render the trial â€œfundamentally unfair.â€

Id. at 310, 604 S.E.2d at 702-03.
Our review of the entire voir dire in this case reveals that Appellant had an impartial jury.Â  As in Hill, the trial court extensively questioned each juror regarding the ability to be fair and impartial, and there is no evidence suggesting that any juror failed in these capacities.Â  Because the evidence in the record supports only the conclusion that Appellant received a fair and impartial jury, and because there is no evidence suggesting that the trial courtâ€™s voir dire limitation rendered Appellantâ€™s trial â€œfundamentally unfair,â€ we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.[1]
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Evidence of Prior Convictions
Appellant argues that the trial court erred in admitting the ABHAN victimsâ€™ mothersâ€™ testimonies, the hospital photographs, and the testimony about the victimâ€™s â€œblack Indiansâ€ dream because this evidence was impermissible â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence of prior crimes.Â  We disagree.
In Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808 (1991), the United States Supreme Court held that the Eighth Amendment did not prohibit a jury from considering â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence at the sentencing phase of a capital trial.Â  In Payne, a brutal double murder, the defendant challenged the admission of testimony that the child of one of the victims â€œmissed his motherâ€ and the Stateâ€™s remarks in closing arguments suggesting that the continuing effects of the crimes on the victimsâ€™ family favored imposing the death penalty.Â  Id. at 816.Â  Drawing on historical arguments and reasons of fairness, the Supreme Court held that a state was not constitutionally prohibited from allowing a capital sentencing jury to consider â€œthe specific harm caused by the defendant,â€ including the impact of the murder on the victimâ€™s family and â€œa quick glimpse of the life which the defendant chose to extinguish.â€Â  Id. at 822-26.
Contrary to Appellantâ€™s assertions, none of the testimony at issue in this case was â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence.Â  First, the mothersâ€™ testimonies were limited to the circumstances surrounding the ABHAN and the extent of the injuries their sons suffered.Â  This evidence was clearly not evidence of the character of the victims or the impact on their families, but rather, evidence of the physical injuries caused by Appellant.Â  That the descriptions of the victimsâ€™ injuries came from their mothers does not automatically convert factually descriptive testimony into impact testimony regarding the victimsâ€™ character or the effect on the victimsâ€™ families or community.
Similarly, there can be no question that the hospital photographs were introduced to describe the extent of the injuries the ABHAN victims suffered.Â  These photographs are easily distinguished from cases where photographs have been deemed â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence. See State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 515 S.E.2d 98 (1999) (photograph of murder victim in his high school graduation regalia); see also State v. Livingston, 327 S.C. 17, 488 S.E.2d 313 (1997) (photograph of victim and her husband taken shortly before victim was involved in fatal accident).Â  Although, like in Langley Â and Livingston, the photographs in this case were certain to elicit an emotional response from the jury, these photographs were highly probative of the nature of Appellantâ€™s prior crime in that they provided the clearest picture of the aggravated nature of the assault and battery.Â  
Finally, we hold the victimâ€™s testimony about his â€œblack Indiansâ€ dream was not â€œvictim impactâ€ evidence.Â  This testimony merely described the emotional injury to the ABHAN victim.Â  
Though masquerading as a horse of the same color, the dissent decides an entirely different case from the one at bar.Â  At the sentencing proceeding, Appellant argued the testimony about the ABHAN victimsâ€™ injuries was â€œinappropriate victim impact type of information having nothing to do with the particular crime Mr. Bennett is on trial for now.â€Â  Likewise, it appears Appellantâ€™s objection to the hospital photographs was based on Rule 403, SCRE (excluding relevant evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice).Â  Finally, Appellant objected to the introduction the victimâ€™s dream on the grounds of relevance.Â  Before this Court, however, Appellant did not couch these objections in terms of relevance or a Rule 403 analysis.Â  Instead, the only theory Appellant presented to this Court on this issue was that this evidence should have been excluded as impermissible victim impact evidence of prior crimes.Â  
Because the evidence in this case was not victim impact evidence, Appellantâ€™s argument must fail.Â  When asked to do so, we will consider arguments regarding the types of evidence of prior crimes that should and should not be admissible in a capital sentencing proceeding.[2] Â However, we feel that the delicate task of balancing the duty to conduct a sentencing inquiry â€œbroad in scope,â€ Dawson, 503 U.S. at 164, against the need to protect a capital defendant from unfair prejudice and prevent a capital sentencing proceeding from transmuting into a sentencing referendum on all of the defendantâ€™s prior crimes is only properly performed when that case is presented.Â  Such a case would no doubt involve considerations of when the introduction of evidence renders a proceeding so unfair as to violate due process, see Payne, 501 U.S. at 831, and also would implicate our rules of evidence; rules which, at the most basic level, allow proof of character by specific instances of conduct.Â  See Rule 405, SCRE.
Instead of addressing any of these topics, which would be of paramount importance when considering clarifying our relevance rules, the briefs to this Court, like Appellantâ€™s argument, concerned only victim impact evidence.Â  Under these circumstances, we feel the better course is to confine ourselves to a careful analysis of the arguments briefed and presented to us.Â  See State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 69, 406 S.E.2d 315, 328 (1991) (abolishing in favorem vitae review in capital cases).Â  Although the dissent raises intriguing questions, we think it the better course to wait to decide such a case until we are asked.Â  See State v. Prioleau, 345 S.C. 404, 411, 548 S.E.2d 213, 216 (2001) (appellate court will not consider issues not properly presented).
Based on the above reasoning, we hold that the testimony about the ABHAN victimsâ€™ injuries and the corresponding photographs was not impermissible victim impact evidence relating to Appellantâ€™s prior crimes.
III.Â Â Â  Alleged Inappropriate Remarks
Appellant argues that the Solicitorâ€™s comments during cross-examination of a witness and during closing arguments improperly injected racial issues into the trial.Â  We disagree.
As a general rule, inflammatory remarks which are calculated to appeal to the passions or prejudices of a jury should be affirmatively condemned.Â  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t. v. Nasim, 255 S.C. 406, 411, 179 S.E.2d 211, 213 (1971).Â  â€œ[W]hether or not the particular arguments are so prejudicial as to constitute reversible error depends upon the nature of the utterances and the circumstances under which they were made.â€Â  Id.Â  Under certain circumstances, this Court will grant a new trial despite the aggrieved partyâ€™s failure to contemporaneously object to the argument if the prejudice caused by the argument is clear.Â  Dial v. Niggel Assoc., Inc., 333 S.C. 253, 256, 509 S.E.2d 269, 271 (1998); Toyota of Florence, Inc., v. Lynch, 314 S.C. 257, 263, 442 S.E.2d 611, 615 (1994).
Additionally, a solicitorâ€™s closing arguments in a capital trial should focus on the defendantâ€™s character, his background, and the nature of the crime.Â  State v. Reed, 293 S.C. 515, 519, 362 S.E.2d 13, 15 (1987) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 69, 406 S.E.2d 315, 328 (1991)).Â  The arguments must be viewed in the context of the entire record, and the relevant question is whether the comments infected the trial with unfairness so as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.Â  State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997).
As a starting point, we recognize that the terms â€œblond ladyâ€ and â€œKing Kongâ€ could have racial connotations.Â  However, this courtâ€™s jurisprudence does not prohibit the use of terms with racial meanings, nor does our case law stand for the proposition that arguments or evidence in a case must be void of racial allusions.Â  Instead, this court has recognized that it is impermissible to use race to â€œinflame the passions or prejudicesâ€ of the jury.Â  Accordingly, our inquiry focuses on how these terms were used in Appellantâ€™s case.
In our view, the â€œblond ladyâ€ remark was not made to inflame the passions or prejudices of the jury.Â  If the State had sought to make the race of Appellantâ€™s former lover an issue in this case, we believe they would have elicited evidence to this effect while examining their witness who testified extensively about the affair.Â  Instead, this comment came while cross-examining a defense witness.Â  
Furthermore, we find that even if this remark was inflammatory, it did not prejudice Appellant.Â  This remark is a far cry from the outrageous and inflammatory evidence and arguments seen in Nasim, Toyota, Dial, and the cases cited by Appellant.Â  The proper inquiry is not whether the Solicitorâ€™s remark was undesirable or condemnable, but whether the comment â€œso infected the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€Â  Darden v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 168, 181 (1986).Â  In this case, the Solicitor made the â€œblond ladyâ€ comment only once and never referred to Appellantâ€™s loverâ€™s race again.Â  Furthermore, this case involved a brutal murder, where guilt was clearly established.Â  Accordingly, we find no evidence of prejudice from the â€œblond ladyâ€ remark.
Similarly, the Solicitorâ€™s use of the term â€œKing Kongâ€ was not an appeal to the passions or prejudices of the jury.Â  The comment referred to Appellantâ€™s immense size, strength, and the destructiveness of his previous crimes.Â  In this case, the trial court properly determined that Appellantâ€™s size and strength were probative of the aggravating circumstance of physical torture, which the court charged to the jury.Â  In this regard, the Solicitorâ€™s use of the term â€œKing Kongâ€ was not suggestive of a giant black gorilla who abducts a white woman, but rather, descriptive of Appellantâ€™s size and strength as they related to his past crimes.
Also, Appellantâ€™s mitigation witnesses described him as â€œa gentle giant,â€ â€œa big old teddy bear,â€ â€œthe Secretary of Defense,â€ and â€œthe Mediator.â€Â  The defense used these terms to indicate Appellant was a changed man and not a threat to others.Â  In this regard, the trial court correctly found that â€œKing Kongâ€ was an invited response to Appellantâ€™s mitigation evidence.Â  
Finally, the Solicitorâ€™s â€œCavemanâ€ comment was merely descriptive of two of Appellantâ€™s past violent incidents.Â  A witness to Appellantâ€™s ABHAN testified that she saw Appellant dragging the motionless body of one of the victims across a parking lot by the hair.Â  Additionally, a prison guard testified about an incident where Appellant reached into another inmateâ€™s cell and dragged the inmate out by the hair.Â  The Solicitor made this comment while describing how Appellant dragged his victims during these incidents, and, in our view, the comment was not inflammatory.
Based on the above reasoning, we hold that the Solicitorâ€™s comments did not improperly inject racial issues into the trial.[3]
Proportionality Review
As required, we conduct a proportionality review of Appellantâ€™s death sentence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C) (2003).Â  The United States Constitution prohibits the imposition of the death penalty when it is either excessive or disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  State v. Copeland, 278 S.C. 572, 590, 300 S.E.2d 63, 74 (1982).Â  In conducting a proportionality review, we search for similar cases in which the death sentence has been upheld.Â  Id.; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(E) (2003).
After reviewing the entire record, we conclude that the sentence in this case was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.Â  Furthermore, a review of similar prior cases illustrates that imposing the death sentence in this case would be neither excessive nor disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  See State v. Huggins, 336 S.C. 200, 205, 519 S.E.2d 574, 577 (1999) (holding that the death penalty was warranted where defendant robbed and shot the victim); State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 219, 499 S.E.2d 209, 216
(1998) (holding that the death penalty was proper where the defendant robbed the victim and stabbed him numerous times in the neck, chest, and abdomen); and State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 120, 485 S.E.2d 360, 367 (1997) (holding that death sentence was proper where the defendant entered the victimâ€™s home, stabbed her to death, and stole the victimâ€™s handbag and automobile).
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm.
 MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J.,Â  dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  In 1988, twelve years before he murdered Benton Smith, appellant brutally assaulted two young men in a parking lot.Â  He pled guilty to two counts of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN), and received a Youthful Offender Act sentence.Â  During this capital resentencing proceeding, the State introduced, without objection, graphic testimony from two eyewitnesses to the assault of the second ABHAN victim,[4] including one witness who observed appellant stomping on the unconscious victimâ€™s head.Â  The second witness testified he saw appellant drag the prostrate victim by the hair, then kneel to punch him five or six times, then rise and kick and stomp the unconscious victim.
The State then called one of the victimsâ€™ mothers to testify, and appellant objected on the grounds of relevance at a sidebar.[5]Â  The objection was overruled, and the mother testified to receiving the call telling her to come to the hospital and the injuries to her son that she observed when she arrived.Â  Over another relevancy objection, the State was permitted to introduce a photo of the victim taken while he was in intensive care.Â  The mother was permitted to testify extensively to the details of her sonâ€™s time in the hospital, his subsequent stay in a head trauma rehabilitation facility, and the lingering effects of the beating.
This motherâ€™s testimony was followed by that of her son.Â  Appellantâ€™s objection at a sidebar, again on the ground of relevancy, was overruled and the victim was permitted to relate a dream he had had while hospitalized about being chased by â€œBlack Indians.â€Â  The State then called, over another unsuccessful relevancy objection, the mother of the second victim.Â  This woman testified, as had the first mother, to her observations of her sonâ€™s injuries, recovery, rehabilitation, and residual problems.
I agree with the majority that evidence of a defendantâ€™s prior criminal record is admissible in a capital sentencing proceeding because it is relevant evidence of the defendantâ€™s character.Â  The Constitution requires that the decision whether to impose a death sentence be â€œan individualized determination [made] on the basis of the character of the individual and the circumstances of the crime.â€Â  Zant v. Stephens, 462 U.S. 862, 879 (1983) (italics in original).Â  Further, I agree that, in furtherance of the juryâ€™s understanding of the defendantâ€™s character, the State should not be limited to merely presenting the fact of the prior conviction as it would be were the purpose to impeach the defendantâ€™s veracity.Â  See State v. Gregg, 230 S.C. 222, 95 S.E.2d 255 (1956).Â  I do not agree, however, that the extensive testimony admitted here, from eyewitnesses, victims, and relatives of the victims of offenses wholly unrelated to the capital offense, are relevant to the issue of the appellantâ€™s character.Â  Nor can I agree that the dream of a victim of a prior crime is, under any stretch of the imagination, relevant to â€œthe character of the individual or the circumstances of the [capital] crime.â€ Zant, supra.
The Constitution permits the sentencing authority to consider â€œthe specific harm caused by the crime in questionâ€ through the Stateâ€™s introduction of â€œevidence about the victim and about the impact of the murder on the victimâ€™s familyâ€ because such evidence is relevant to the â€œdefendantâ€™s moral culpability and blameworthinessâ€ as it relates to the capital murder.Â  Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808 (1991).Â  In other words, this type of evidence is admissible because it is relevant to the circumstances of the crime, not because it is relevant to the defendantâ€™s character.Â  Id.Â Â  
I agree with the majority that the Stateâ€™s evidence in this case cannot be characterized as victim-impact evidence under Payne since it does not relate to the murder victim or his family.Â  In fairness to appellantâ€™s attorneys, however, they concede that this evidence would have been admissible under Payne if related to the capital crime rather than to these unrelated prior offenses.Â  Specifically, appellantâ€™s trial objection was to the evidence â€œas being inappropriate, victim impact type information and having nothing to do with the particular trial that [appellant] is on trial for now.â€Â  Moreover, appellantâ€™s attorney in this appeal concedes this type of evidence may be admissible as it relates to the victim of the capital crime, but argues â€œ[t]here is no language in Payne authorizing victim impact evidence on unrelated crimes â€¦.â€ Â I agree with appellant that the trial court erred in admitting this irrelevant evidence.Â  
The Constitution limits even valid victim-impact evidence where it is unduly inflammatory or renders the sentencing proceeding fundamentally unfair.Â  Payne, supra (Justice Oâ€™Connor, concurring).Â  Here, the capital sentencing jury was overwhelmed with evidence of appellantâ€™s â€œmoral culpability and blameworthiness,â€ not for the murder of Benton Smith, but for the brutal beatings of two young men.[6]Â  In my opinion, the Stateâ€™s presentation of this evidence denied appellant a fair sentencing and encouraged the jury to impose a death sentence on an improper basis.Â  Zant, supra (character of the defendant and circumstances of the capital crime are relevant to determining sentence).
I therefore dissent from the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm appellantâ€™s sentence.

[1] Appellant urges us to reconcile a perceived conflict between Hill and our opinion in Appellantâ€™s first appeal before this Court.Â  As we stated in Hill, Bennett did not determine the appropriateness of the â€œgo with the majority question.â€Â  Hill, 361 S.C. at 309, 604 S.E.2d 702.Â  In fact, the only issue in Bennett was whether the questioned juror was â€œunbiased, impartial, and able to carry out the law as executed.â€Â  Id.Â  Although Appellant properly points out that the court might never have discovered the juror in his first trial without the â€œgo with the majorityâ€ question, it is equally true that no amount of questioning can provide a clear picture of a jurorâ€™s biases or tendencies.Â  Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. 412, 424-25 (1985).Â  â€œ[T]hese veniremen may not know how they will react when faced with imposing the death sentence, or may be unable to articulate, or may wish to hide their true feelings.â€Â  Id.Â  This position is strengthened by our previous recognition of the trial judgeâ€™s duty to focus voir dire upon matters enumerated in the death penalty statutes and to eliminate excessive intrusions into the privacy of prospective jurors.Â  State v. Plath, 281 S.C. 1, 7, 313 S.E.2d 619, 622 (1984) (citing State v. Koon, 278 S.C. 528, 532, 298 S.E.2d 769, 771 (1982)).Â  
[2] Academically, South Carolina has long recognized that information about prior convictions is admissible in a capital sentencing proceeding.Â  See State v. Gaskins, 284 S.C. 105, 124, 326 S.E.2d 132, 143 (1985); and State v. Plath, 281 S.C. at 9, 313 S.E.2d at 623 (stating that this rule is so fundamental that it requires no citation of authority).Â  This rule is derived from the principle that receiving evidence of prior crimes is probative of the character of the defendant and consistent with the sentencing authorityâ€™s duty to â€œconduct an inquiry broad in scope, largely unlimited either as to the kind of information he may consider, or the source from which it may come.â€Â  Dawson v. Delaware, 503 U.S. 159, 164 (1992); see also State v. Skipper, 285 S.C. 42, 47, 328 S.E.2d 58, 61 (1985) (overruled on other grounds 476 U.S. 1 (1986)).Â  Appellant has not challenged this rule, and indeed, Appellant has made no discussion of these authorities (upon which the trial court directly relied).
[3] This conclusion makes an analysis of Nasim, Toyota and Dialâ€™s exception to the contemporaneous objection rule unnecessary.Â  
[4]Both victims were lying motionless in the parking lot, â€œobviously injured.â€Â  The scene was quite bloody.
[5] The judge later put the grounds of the objection on the record.
[6] This evidence was exploited by the solicitor in his closing argument.

Burriss case


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
William Mack Burriss, E. Lee McPherson, and Anderson County School District Five,
Appellants,
v.
Anderson County Board of Education, Governor of the State of South Carolina, Lieutenant Governor of the State of South Carolina, and Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26175
Heard May 2, 2006 - Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kenneth L. Childs, William F. Halligan, John M. Reagle, and Keith R. Powell, all of Childs & Halligan, P.A., of Columbia, for Appellants.
Michael J. Giese and Seann Gray Tzouvelekas, both of Leatherwood, Walker, Todd, & Mann, of Greenville, for Respondent Anderson County Board of Education.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster and Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondents Governor of the State of South Carolina, Lieutenant Governor of the State of South Carolina, and Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a direct appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s decision in favor of respondents on cross‑motions for summary judgment.Â  At issue is whether Anderson Countyâ€™s two-tiered school governance system violates the Equal Protection clause of the federal constitution and the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s guarantees of no taxation without representation and uniform taxation within a jurisdiction.  Essentially, appellants argue that these violations stem from the Anderson County Board of Educationâ€™s review authority over the individual districtsâ€™ budgets.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Anderson County has five public school districts each with a popularly elected board of trustees.[1]Â  There is also an Anderson County Board of Education (â€œthe County Boardâ€) composed of nine members popularly elected by single member districts.Â  Each member of the County Board represents approximately 18,739 Anderson County citizens.Â  Anderson County School District Five (â€œDistrict Fiveâ€) represents 42% of the total voting age population (VAP) for the County Boardâ€™s nine seats.Â  Seats 7 and 8 on the County Board are exclusively elected by citizens in District Five; for Seat 9, 97% of those voting reside in District Five.Â  Citizens in District Five also vote for Seats 4, 5, and 6, representing 31%, 25%, and 28%, respectively, of those voting for these seats.Â  For Seat 1, 99% of those voting reside in Anderson County School District Four.Â  
The annual budget for each school district is developed through an interactive process between the individual districts and the County Board; however, the County Board exercises review and approval authority over each of the school districtsâ€™ budgets.Â  Ultimately, it is the County Board that sets the school operations tax millage rates for each school district. [2] 
The County Boardâ€™s budgetary review authority dates at least as far back as 1950.Â  See 1950 S.C. Acts 868, Â§ 38.[3]Â  This authority over the budget was referenced again in 1982 when the Legislature provided that: 

the Anderson County Board of Education shall be vested with the power to review and approve the budget of the school districts and shall further be vested with the power to review an approve requests by the school districts for any increase or decrease in taxation or millage in keeping with the needs of each school district and the requirements of the â€¦ Education Finance Act.

1982 S.C. Acts 510, Â§ 9.Â  That same year, another Act authorized an advisory referendum in Anderson County to determine if the electors of the County favored an elected County Board of Education with review authority over the local elected school district boardsâ€™ budgets. Â 1982 S.C. Acts 511, Â§ 1.Â  The voters overwhelmingly endorsed the County Boardâ€™s review authority. [4] 
Nevertheless, the County Board has not often exercised its authority over the individual districtsâ€™ budgets, but instead has generally approved the budgets submitted by the districts.Â  From 1997-2002, a total of 29 budgets were submitted to the County Board by the five school districts, and the County Board approved 28 of them.Â  However, the County Board did not approve District Fiveâ€™s proposed budget for the 2001-2002 school year.Â  This proposed budget, which had been approved by District Fiveâ€™s Board of Trustees, was in the amount of $63,274,082.Â  The County Board ultimately reduced District Fiveâ€™s 2001-2002 budget by $750,000.Â  Eight of the nine County Board members voted for this reduction.
In addition to its budgetary review function, the County Board also serves other functions.Â  For example, the County operates and finances an Alternative School that is open to any child in Anderson County.Â  The Alternative School is designed to serve students with special needs such as chronic discipline and truancy problems.Â  District Five students attend the County-run Alternative School. 
The County Board also administers the following programs:Â  (1) food service programs to Districts One, Two, Three, and Four; (2) mental health counseling to students in Districts One, Two, Three, and Four, as well as the Alternative School; and (3) attendance monitoring and dropout prevention services to students in Districts One, Two, Three, and Four, and the Alternative School. Â Although these programs are not administered to District Five, it appears from the Record on Appeal this is because the District has opted to provide its own district-run programs.[5]Â  
Finally, the County Board administers the county-wide equalization tax.Â  This equalization tax, in practice, amounts to a levy of 14.7 mills which is imposed and collected uniformly on the Countyâ€™s assessed value and is then distributed by the County Board to the local districts based upon student average daily membership.Â  According to the County Boardâ€™s Administrator, the equalization tax is a â€œcounty-wide effort to spread the Countyâ€™s wealth in an effort to see that per pupil spending does not vary too dramatically from district to district.â€ [6] 
Other than their involvement with the County Board in the budget process, the five local school districts are generally autonomous in other areas of school governance, such as the hiring and firing of teachers, setting guidelines for student discipline, and creating extracurricular student activities.Â  The school districts perform these functions without interference from, or supervision by, the County Board.Â  
Appellant William Mack Burriss is the chairman of the Anderson County School District Five Board of Trustees, and he resides in District Five.Â  Appellant E. Lee McPherson is the chairman of the Anderson County School District Four Board of Trustees, and he resides in District Four.Â  District Five itself is the third appellant in this case.Â  In 2002, these appellants brought a declaratory action in circuit court against the County Board, as well as the following â€œStateâ€ respondents: the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
Appellants and the County Board subsequently filed cross-motions for summary judgment.Â  In April 2004, the circuit court granted the County Boardâ€™s summary judgment motion and dismissed the complaint as to the County Board and the State respondents.Â  The circuit court found that the statutory scheme giving the County Board review authority over District Fiveâ€™s budget was constitutional.Â  The circuit court further ruled that Anderson Countyâ€™s two-tiered governance system did not violate the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s bans against: (1) taxation without representation; and (2) non-uniform taxation.Â  See S.C. Const. Art. X, Â§Â§ 5 & 6.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the circuit court err in finding that the statutory scheme giving the County Board budget review authority over the districts is constitutional under the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        II. 
         Did the circuit court err in ruling that the County Boardâ€™s tax authority over the individual school districts does not violate the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s ban against taxation without representation, pursuant to Article X, Section 5?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        III. 
         Did the circuit court err in ruling that the County Boardâ€™s tax authority over the individual school districts does not violate the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s ban against non-uniform taxation within a jurisdiction, pursuant to Article X, Section 6?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
I. Â Equal Protection
Appellants argue that Anderson Countyâ€™s two-tiered school governance system creates an â€œover-inclusive franchiseâ€ which dilutes the voting rights of those residing in District Four and Five.Â  Specifically, appellants contend that because the budgets and tax rates for these districts are ultimately determined by the County Board, which contains members who are elected by voters who live outside Districts Four and Five, the strength of their own votes is diluted.Â  Appellants assert that this vote dilution runs afoul of the federal Equal Protection Clauseâ€™s[7] principle of â€œone person, one vote.â€Â  We disagree.
This Court reviews the grant of a summary judgment motion under the same standard as the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP:Â  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  E.g., Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438-39 (2003).
Under the South Carolina Constitution, the Legislature is charged with â€œprovid[ing] for the maintenance and support of a system of free public schools open to all children in the State.â€Â  S.C. Const. art. XI, Â§ 3.Â  The Legislature â€œhas wide discretion in determining how to go about accomplishing [this] duty.â€ Â Horry County Sch. Dist. v. Horry County, 346 S.C. 621, 632, 552 S.E.2d 737, 743 (2001).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]ll statutes are presumed constitutional and will, if possible, be construed so as to render them valid.â€Â  Id. at 631, 552 S.E.2d at 742.Â  
Without question, equal protection guarantees â€œone person, one vote.â€Â  Gray v. Sanders, 372 U.S. 368, 381 (1963).Â  The United States Supreme Court has recognized that an absolute ban on the franchise is not the only way a citizenâ€™s voting right can be abridged:Â  â€œthe right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizenâ€™s vote just as effectively as by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise.â€Â  Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 555 (1964).Â  Indeed, â€œvote dilution is as nefarious as an outright prohibition on voting.â€ Â Duncan v. Coffee County, Tenn., 69 F.3d 88, 93 (6th Cir. 1995).
Nonetheless, in the local government context, â€œnormal public policy makingâ€ of the State can include expanding the franchise beyond the required electorate provided no unconstitutional vote dilution results.Â  Id. at 94.Â  Moreover, the courts have observed that â€œoverinclusiveness is less of a constitutional evil than underinclusiveness.â€Â  Sutton v. Escambia County Bd. of Educ., 809 F.2d 770, 775 (11th Cir. 1987); accord Duncan, 69 F.3d at 98.[8]
The federal courts generally have applied rational basis review to evaluate this type of overinclusion, or expanded electorate, claim.Â  For example, the Eleventh Circuit has stated that â€œ[t]he party seeking to exclude â€¦ residents from voting in the county school board elections has the burden of demonstrating that the application of the [State] statute â€¦ is irrational or wholly irrelevant to the stateâ€™s objective of electoral participation in the selection of county school board members.â€Â  Sutton, 809 F.2d at 772; see also Duncan, 69 F.3d at 95 (discussing Sutton standard with approval).Â  But see Locklear v. North Carolina State Bd. of Elections, 514 F.2d 1152 (4th Cir. 1975) (applying compelling state interest standard).[9]
The federal courts have determined whether the State statute survives this rational basis standard by further inquiring whether the expanded electorate has a â€œsubstantial interestâ€ in the operation of the relevant school system. Â E.g., Duncan, 69 F.3d at 95; Phillips v. Andress, 634 F.2d 947 (5th Cir. 1981); Creel v. Freeman, 531 F.2d 286 (5th Cir. 1976), cert. denied, 429 U.S. 1066 (1977).Â  Moreover, the Duncan court noted that four factors have emerged to determine substantial interest:

1. The degree to which one district is financing the other; 
2. The voting strength of the non-resident voters; 
3. The number of, or potential for, cross-over students; and
4. The existence of any joint programs.

Duncan, 69 F.3d at 96.Â  
Nevertheless, the Sixth Circuit in Duncan observed that the substantial interest test has been difficult â€œto apply consistently,â€ id. at 95, and the several federal cases have had divergent results.Â  Compare Duncan, Sutton, and Creel (all finding that the city residents had a substantial interest in the operation of the county school system thereby justifying their votes in county school board elections) with Hogencamp v. Lee County Bd. of Ed., 722 F.2d 720 (11th Cir. 1984), Phillips, and Locklear (all holding that the city residents did not have a substantial interest in the operation of the county school system thereby diluting the voting strength of the other county residents).Â  One commentator has noted the fact-specific nature of these cases:

The overlapping school district disputes have generated an unusual series of local voting cases in which both the stateâ€™s interest in structuring local governments and the primary local constituencyâ€™s interest in avoiding dilution have been weighed and the disputes have been resolved through a fact-sensitive consideration of the extent of city involvement in county schools.

Briffault, 60 U. Chi. L. Rev. at 398.
We concur with the majority of federal courts that have faced this issue the appropriate inquiry in an expanded electorate case is the rational basis test.Â  Thus, to prevail, appellants must demonstrate that the Stateâ€™s decision to structure the Anderson County public education system as a two-tiered system which vests the County Board with review authority over the individual districtsâ€™ budgets is irrational.Â  See Duncan, 69 F.3d at 95; Sutton, 809 F.2d at 772.Â  Moreover, this particular rational basis review appropriately focuses on whether the out-of-district voters have a substantial interest in the operation of the relevant school system.Â  See, e.g., Duncan, 69 F.3d at 95. Â Finally, because of the fact-intensive character of these cases, we note that while the Duncan factors often may be useful for the inquiry, they are not the exclusive factors to be taken into consideration.Â  We do, however, begin our analysis with the Duncan factors.
1. The degree to which one district is financing the other
Appellants argue this factor weighs in their favor since they claim Districts Four and Five are net donor districts.Â  However, appellants also argue that even if these Districts are net recipient districts, the amount is negligible when compared to the districtsâ€™ overall budgets, and therefore, would not weigh in favor of finding a substantial interest for the â€œextraterritorialâ€ voters.
The federal courts have often relied heavily on this factor.Â  See, e.g., Duncan, 69 F.3d at 96 (finding that because the City provided a substantial amount from its own sales and property taxes to the County, and the funds made up a â€œsizableâ€ portion of the recipientâ€™s budget (7.28%), the City votes were supported by a substantial interest); Hogencamp, 722 F.2d at 722 (finding that the Cityâ€™s contribution of money in the amount of 2.74% of the County boardâ€™s budget did not support a finding of substantial interest).Â  Yet, financial contribution is not determinative.Â  See Sutton, 809 F.2d at 774 (where the facts did not show the Cityâ€™s financial participation in the County, but did establish a strong relationship between the two school systems, the court held that City residents had substantial interest in operation of County school system and could vote in county school board elections).
In the instant case, there is an equalization tax which, in effect, spreads the wealth in Anderson County among the individual districts.Â  The equalization levyâ€™s goal is to create a financial in-flow to the districts that need more money, which necessarily will create an out-flow from wealthier districts.Â  Moreover, because this levy represents a County-wide effort to distribute the Countyâ€™s wealth, and appellants do not object to the formula, it appears all the Anderson County districts participate in the financing of one another which, consequently, indicates that the out-of-district voters have a substantial interest in the other districts.Â  We therefore agree with the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that the equalization tax justifies County Boardâ€™s involvement with the districtsâ€™ budgets.
2. The voting strength of the non-resident voters
Appellants argue that because District Four is served by only one County Board member, and District Five â€œonlyâ€ has a controlling vote for three County Board seats, this factor weighs in their favor.Â  Appellants further claim that because the County Board has review authority over each district, and out-of-district residents collectively have more County Board votes than the single district affected by the County Boardâ€™s decision, this â€œcontrolâ€ amounts to unconstitutional vote dilution.Â  We disagree.
The underlying premise of a representative government is that citizens vote for a representative and that person then represents his or her constituents in the governing body.Â  However, appellants contend that because District Four and District Five are unable to attain majority control of the County Board, the County Boardâ€™s taxation power is rendered unconstitutional.Â  On the contrary, as the County Board points out, Districts Four and Five collectively wield significant influence in a County Board election, with both districts able to completely control four seats (out of nine) on the County Board, and District Five able to cast a substantial minority vote in another three seats.Â  This factor clearly favors the County Board.
3. The number of, or potential for, cross-over students
The circuit court found that because the Countyâ€™s Alternative School serves students residing in all five school districts, â€œeducationÂ  in Anderson County is a collective undertaking and â€¦ county-wide involvement is warranted.â€Â  We agree that the Alternative School demonstrates that cross-over students exist in Anderson County. Â Because voters in all the districts have a substantial interest in this county-run school, this factor favors the County Board. 
Appellants maintain, however, that there is no student crossover between the school districts themselves, and therefore this shows no substantial interest on the part of the â€œextraterritorialâ€ voters.Â  The basic flaw in appellantâ€™s argument is that these â€œout-of-districtâ€ voters are not voting for the districtâ€™s own trustees, but rather for seats on the County Board.Â  Hence, the relevant inquiry is whether any cross-over students exist within the County, regardless of whether that is between the districts themselves or between a district and the County.Â  Because there is some evident cross-over, this factor weighs in favor of the â€œextraterritorialâ€ votersâ€™ substantial interest.
4. The existence of any joint programs
The circuit court found that the County Board administers programs related to mental health counseling, food services, attendance monitoring, and dropout prevention.Â  Appellants, however, maintain there are no joint programs.Â  Their argument relies on the facts that the County Boardâ€™s programs are not joint vis-Ã -vis the districts and District Five does not receive these services.
We hold the circuit court correctly found that the County Boardâ€™s programs regarding mental health counseling, food services, attendance monitoring, and dropout prevention are evidence in support of this factor.Â  District Five apparently has chosen not to avail itself of any of these programs, but that should not weigh against the County Board or negate the programsâ€™ existence; these programs clearly affect the overwhelming majority of the school districts.
Moreover, it is undisputed that the Alternative School is run by the County Board and it serves students from all five districts.Â  This is an additional joint program; the voters from all five districts clearly have a substantial interest in the Countyâ€™s operation of the Alternative School.
5.Â  Other Relevant Factors
In addition to the four Duncan factors, the circuit court also noted â€œother county-wide interests that warrant county-wide involvementâ€ in the individual school districtsâ€™ budgets.[10]Â  
The circuit court found that the County Board provided â€œa number of fiscal services for the districtsâ€ related to tax collection and distribution, including the equalization tax.Â  The circuit court also noted the County Boardâ€™s review authority over the budgets. Â Finally, the circuit court found that every resident of a South Carolina county has a substantial interest in the education of the children of that particular county. Â In support of this latter finding, the circuit court cited the testimony of Dr. James Guthrie, a professor of public policy and education.Â  
Dr. Guthrie, provided deposition testimony as an expert on behalf of the County Board.Â  Dr. Guthrie stated that â€œ[a]ll the residents of Anderson County hold the prospect of benefiting from the educational programsâ€ in District Five because of what economists label â€œneighborhoodâ€ or â€œspilloverâ€ effects.Â  In Dr. Guthrieâ€™s opinion, the closer oneâ€™s proximity to someone in District Five, â€œthe greater or more intense the likelihood that spillover effectâ€ would pertain to that person.
Dr. Guthrie also testified that virtually every State he was familiar with, with the exception of Hawaii, had an intermediate government body between a State education department and a local school district; moreover, Dr. Guthrie stated that these intermediate bodies frequently have the authority to oversee the local school districtsâ€™ budget.Â  According to Dr. Guthrie, public policy supports the use of an intermediate body because it leads to â€œeconomy-of-scale,â€ i.e., a more efficient use of â€œotherwise scarce resources.â€Â  In addition, the intermediate body serves a regulatory function as an arm of the State.Â  Dr. Guthrie explained that this is â€œa part of trying to balance remote, centralized state government with, presumably, local and locally sensitive and responsive local school boardsâ€ which he believed was â€œa reasonable activity.â€ 
We agree with the circuit court that in South Carolina it is not unreasonable for County residents to have a substantial interest in the education of other County residents, even if they reside in a different school district. Â Dr. Guthrieâ€™s â€œneighborhood effectsâ€ testimony amply supports this conclusion.Â  Moreover, as recognized by the circuit court, â€œthe county unit is an essential part of every South Carolinianâ€™s existence.â€ See S.C. Const. art. VIII, Â§ 7 (establishing Home Rule).Â  The various financial functions performed by the County Board, including those ministerial functions related to the equalization levy, clearly are rationally related to the Stateâ€™s objective in giving counties home rule and also are reasonably consistent with the Stateâ€™s decision to give the County Board budgetary review authority.
In sum, we hold that the Stateâ€™s authorization of a popularly elected County school board with review authority over the individual Anderson County school districtsâ€™ budgets is neither â€œirrationalâ€ nor â€œwholly irrelevantâ€ to the Stateâ€™s goals in efficiently providing public education. Â Sutton, 809 F.2d at 772.Â  As the United States Supreme Court has noted, â€œ[t]he Constitution does not require that a uniform straitjacket bind citizens in devising mechanisms of local government suitable for local needs and efficient in solving local problems.â€ Â Avery v. Midland County, 390 U.S. 474, 485 (1968).Â  Furthermore, the Constitution should not be a â€œroadblock[] in the path of innovation, experiment, and development among units of local government.â€Â  Id.Â  The Stateâ€™s establishment of the two-tiered school governance in Anderson County does not result in vote dilution and therefore does not offend the Equal Protectionâ€™s guarantee of â€œone person, one vote.â€Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling on this issue.
II.Â  No Taxation without Representation
Appellants next argue that because the County Board votes on an individual school districtâ€™s budget and tax levy, yet the County Board does not directly, i.e. exclusively, represent just a single district, these tax decisions can never be â€œdirectly corrected by those who must carry the burden of the tax.â€ Â Crow v. McAlpine, 277 S.C. 240, 245, 285 S.E.2d 355, 358 (1981).Â  Appellants contend this violates Article X, Section 5 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  We are unpersuaded by appellantsâ€™ argument.
The State Constitution provides that â€œ[n]o tax, subsidy or charge shall be established, fixed, laid or levied, under any pretext whatsoever, without the consent of the people or their representatives lawfully assembled.â€Â  S.C. Const. art. X, Â§ 5.Â  This Court has held that the Legislature cannot, â€œconsistent with Article X, Section 5, delegate the unrestricted power of taxationâ€ to a County school board composed exclusively of members appointed by the Governor.Â  Crow v. McAlpine, 277 S.C. at 245, 285 S.E.2d at 358.Â  The Court in Crow v. McAlpine stated that â€œ[w]here the power is delegated to a body composed of persons not assented to by the people nor subject to the supervisory control of a body chosen by the people,â€ Article X, Section 5, is violated.Â  Id. at 244, 285 S.E.2d at 358 (emphasis added).Â  This Court has also noted that â€œ[d]elegation of the taxing power should be kept with supervisory control always vested in elective bodies.â€Â  Bradley v. Cherokee Sch. Dist. No. One of Cherokee County, 322 S.C. 181, 184, 470 S.E.2d 570, 571 (1996).
In the instant case, the taxation power at issue is vested in an elective body (the County Board) which is â€œchosen by the peopleâ€ of Anderson County.Â  Therefore, there is no violation Article X, Section 5 of the State constitution.Â  See Bradley; Crow v. McAlpine.
The County Board consists of nine seats elected by single member districts representing approximately 18,739 Anderson County residents.Â  The Legislature has authorized this popularly elected board with taxation authority.Â  See 1982 S.C. Acts 510, Â§ 9; 1950 S.C. Acts 868, Â§ 38.Â  Additionally, the people of Anderson County in the 1982 referendum overwhelmingly voted in favor of the County Board having review authority over the school districtsâ€™ budgets.Â  Finally, contrary to the appellantsâ€™ assertions, â€œthe power to fix and levyâ€ Anderson Countyâ€™s school tax has been appropriately conferred upon the County Board, which indeed is â€œa body which stands as the direct representative of the people, [such] that an abuse of power may be directly corrected by those who must carry the burden of the tax.â€ Â Crow v. McAlpine, 277 S.C. at 244-45, 285 S.E.2d at 358.
Regarding this issue, the circuit court stated the following:Â  â€œThe mere fact that voters in the individual school districts directly elect fewer than all of the Board members who make decisions affecting those districts does not subject those voters to taxation without representation.â€Â  We agree and therefore affirm summary judgment on this issue as well.
III.Â  Uniform Taxation
Finally, Appellants argue that the County Boardâ€™s review authority enables it to impose different tax levies on the five school districts in violation of the State Constitutionâ€™s general rule against non-uniform taxation.Â  See S.C. Const. art. X, Â§ 6.Â  We disagree.
Article X, section 6 of the South Carolina Constitution, entitled â€œAssessment and collection of taxes in political subdivisions,â€ reads as follows, in pertinent part:

The General Assembly may vest the power of assessing and collecting taxes in all of the political subdivisions of the State. Property tax levies shall be uniform in respect to persons and property within the jurisdiction of the body imposing such taxes; provided, that on properties located in an area receiving special benefits from the taxes collected, special levies may be permitted by general law applicable to the same type of political subdivision throughout the State, and the General Assembly shall specify the precise condition under which such special levies shall be assessed.

Id.
Appellants maintain that because the County Board represents the political subdivision of the County, this constitutional provision prevents the County Board from making different assessments for the individual school districts which represent five different political subdivisions.Â  The County Board, on the other hand, asserts that the provisionâ€™s â€œspecial leviesâ€ exception to the uniformity requirement applies to the school districts because the districts receive the â€œspecial benefitsâ€ from the school taxes.Â  Specifically, the County Board argues that several state statutes establish the applicability of this exception, including S.C. Code Section 4-9-70, the Education Finance Act of 1977 (â€œEFAâ€), and the Education Improvement Act (â€œEIAâ€).[11]
Section 4-9-70, which is part of the Home Rule Act, states that â€œthe county council shall determine by ordinance the method of establishing the school tax millage except in those cases where boards of trustees of the districts or the county board of education established such millage at the time â€¦ this chapter becomes effective.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-70 (1976) (emphasis added).Â  This Court discussed the legislative intent of section 4-9-70 in Stone v. Traynham, 278 S.C. 407, 297 S.E.2d 420 (1982): 

By enacting Â§ 4- 9-70, the General Assembly attempted to insure that the taxing power for all school districts would be properly vested in some authority. The clear intent is to vest the power to determine the school tax levy in county council in all cases where it is not vested elsewhere.

Id. at 410, 297 S.E.2d at 422 (emphasis added).Â  This statute went into effect in 1975, well after the County Board had been authorized to set the school tax millage.Â  See 1950 S.C. Acts 868, Â§ 38.[12]
Based on this Courtâ€™s statement on Section 4-9-70â€™s intent in Stone v. Traynham, it is clear the Legislature envisioned that the County Board would set different millage rates for the individual Anderson County school districts.Â  Furthermore, we agree with the County Board that both the EFA and the EIA inherently contemplate that millage rates will vary among school districts within a single county.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-20-30(6) (stating that one of the legislative purposes of the statute is to require each local school district â€œto contribute its fair shareâ€ relative to its â€œtaxpaying abilityâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-21-1030 (local financial effort adjusted annually by inflation factor).Â  Given that these several statutes support the County Boardâ€™s argument that the special levies exception of Article X, Section 6 applies to school taxes, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s summary judgment ruling on this issue.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, the circuit courtâ€™s decision to grant the County Boardâ€™s summary judgment motion and to dismiss the complaint against all respondents is
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Anderson County School District Two extends into a part of Greenville County.
[2] This is not a situation unique to Anderson County.Â  According to the Anderson County Administrator, 46 of South Carolinaâ€™s school districts must â€œgo to a higher body (legislative delegation, county council, or county board) to get their budgets approved, or to raise the millage beyond a certain point,â€ while 23 South Carolina school districts are â€œindependent.â€
[3]  This section of Act 868 provides that the district Board of Trustees â€œshall certify to the County Board the amount of levy upon the taxable property in its district which â€¦ is necessary â€¦ for the proper operation of the schoolsâ€ and then â€œ[u]pon the County Board approving such levy â€¦ [the] Board shall notify the auditor of [Anderson] county the amount of such levy for such school district.â€Â  The Act further provides that if any individual school district â€œfails to certify the amount of such levy,â€ the County Board â€œshall determine the amount of such levy for such school district and notify the Auditor.â€ Â 1950 S.C. Acts 868, Â§ 38.
[4] The results of the referendum were that 69 of the Countyâ€™s 74 precincts (93% of the precincts) voted yes.
[5] For example, the brochure describing the County Boardâ€™s mental health program indicates it is open to District Five.Â  District Five, however, had its own pre-existing program to provide therapeutic services to students.Â  Furthermore, District Five provides its own attendance and school food service programs.
[6] Appellants do not oppose the formula or the purpose of the equalization tax.Â  Appellants do, however, assert that District Five is a â€œnet donorâ€ in this equalization scheme.Â  The County Board, on the other hand, claims that District Five received more in equalization revenue than it paid in equalization taxes. 
[7] U.S. Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1.
[8] See also Richard Briffault, Who Rules at Home?: One Person/One Vote and Local Governments, 60 U. Chi. L. Rev 339, 396-400 (1993) (discussing â€œexpanded electorate/overlapping jurisdictionâ€ cases which involved claims that a State improperly extended the local franchise and thereby unconstitutionally diluted the primary local votes, but finding that most extensions of the franchise have been sustained).Â  
[9] The strict scrutiny test employed in the Fourth Circuitâ€™s Locklear decision has not been followed by any other circuit. Â See Duncan, 69 F.3d at 94 (rejecting the Fourth Circuit standard â€œto the extent it still governsâ€).Â  Indeed, Locklear is recognized as â€œthe exception.â€Â  Briffault, 60 U. Chi. L. Rev. at 397 n.232.
[10] We note that these considerations, while not contemplated by the Duncan factors, are relevant to the rational basis inquiry because, as explained above, the inquiry into the constitutionality of an expanded electorate is highly fact-specific.Â  
[11] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-20-10 et seq. (2004) (EFA); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 59-21-1030 (2004) (EIA).Â  These statutes, inter alia, set minimums for local school district funding via formulas calculated annually.
[12] Appellants assert that 1966 S.C. Acts 1080 establishes that the County Board did not have authority to set the school millage in 1975.Â  The 1966 Act provided that the Anderson County school districts could not increase the tax levy more than five mills in a year without a referendum.Â  We agree with the County Board that this legislative act simply set a maximum millage increase but did not affect the County Boardâ€™s review authority which was established as early as 1950 and has been subsequently referenced by the Legislature.Â  See 1950 S.C. Acts 868, Â§ 38; 1982 S.C. Acts 510, Â§ 9; see also 1989 S.C. Acts 269, Â§ 1(B) (stating that the districts shall annually â€œrecommendâ€ to the County Board the amount of tax millage needed for the budget).

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Henry H. Cabaniss,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26176
Submitted May 30, 2006 - Filed June 26, 2006

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Henry H. Cabaniss, of Davidson, N.C., pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a twelve month suspension from the practice of law.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a twelve month suspension, retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Cabaniss, ___ S.C. ___, 629 S.E.2d 353 (2005).Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
